summary.en: Entbraldom means a state of being controlled or held captive, literally or emotionally—often used in formal or literary writing.
summary.zh: Entbraldom 指被控制或被束缚的状态（字面或情感/心理层面），常见于正式或文学表达中。

definition.en: A state of being controlled, trapped, or held in bondage—physically or mentally; sometimes the condition of being completely captivated by someone or something.
definition.zh: 被控制、受奴役或被束缚的状态（身体上或精神上）；也可指被某人/某物深深吸引而“着迷”的状态。

examples.en: He longed to escape the enthraldom of debt.
examples.zh: 他渴望摆脱债务的束缚。

examples.en: The novel portrays a nation in the enthraldom of fear and propaganda.
examples.zh: 这部小说描绘了一个被恐惧与宣传所控制的国家。

examples.en: She finally broke free from the enthraldom of an unhealthy relationship.
examples.zh: 她终于摆脱了一段不健康关系的控制。

extraExplanation: “enthraldom”较偏文学/正式用语，常见于写作中用来强调“被某种力量支配”的感觉（如恐惧、成瘾、权力、债务、关系）。
词源上与“thrall（奴仆、被奴役的人）”有关，因此带有“失去自由/自主”的语感；在现代语境中也常被引申为“被强烈吸引而无法自拔”。

summary.en: Enthrall means to fascinate and hold someone’s attention completely; in older/literary use it can mean to enslave.
summary.zh: enthrall 指“使人着迷、全神贯注”；在较旧或文学用法中也可指“奴役、使受束缚”。

definition.en: to capture someone’s full attention and interest; to fascinate or hold spellbound
definition.zh: 使某人全神贯注；迷住；吸引得入迷

examples.en: The storyteller enthralled the children with a mystery tale.
examples.zh: 讲故事的人用一则神秘故事把孩子们听得入了迷。

examples.en: I was enthralled by the documentary’s beautiful images and music.
examples.zh: 我被那部纪录片的唯美画面和音乐深深吸引。

examples.en: Her performance enthralled the audience from start to finish.
examples.zh: 她的表演从头到尾都牢牢抓住了观众的注意力。

definition.en: (older or literary) to enslave or hold someone in bondage
definition.zh: （较旧或文学用法）奴役；使受束缚

examples.en: In the legend, the villain enthralled the villagers through fear.
examples.zh: 在传说中，反派用恐惧奴役了村民。

examples.en: The poem warns against being enthralled by greed.
examples.zh: 这首诗警示人们不要被贪欲所奴役。

extraExplanation: “Enthrall”来自“thralldom（奴役、束缚）”的词源，早期更偏“使为奴”的意思；现代日常英语中几乎主要用来表示“迷住、使入迷”。
常见搭配：be enthralled by…（被……迷住）；enthrall someone with…（用……吸引/迷住某人）。
语体提示：比“interest”更强烈、更有文学色彩，常用于描述故事、表演、电影、演讲等“抓住注意力”的效果。

summary.en: Enthralldom means a state of being deeply captivated—or, more rarely and more literally, a state of bondage or enslavement.
summary.zh: enthralldom 指“深深着迷的状态”；更少见也更字面地指“受束缚/被奴役的状态”。

definition.en: a state of being completely fascinated by something or someone; being held under strong influence (sometimes with the feeling of being “captured” by it)
definition.zh: 着迷、被深深吸引的状态；在强烈影响之下（有时带有“被俘获/被控制”的感觉）

examples.en: The audience sat in enthralldom as the storyteller’s voice rose and fell.
examples.zh: 说书人的声音抑扬顿挫，观众听得如痴如醉。

examples.en: She lived in enthralldom to the idea of success, always chasing the next goal.
examples.zh: 她对“成功”这个念头近乎痴迷，总是在追逐下一个目标。

definition.en: the condition of being enslaved or in bondage; servitude (rare, more literary)
definition.zh: 被奴役、受束缚的处境；奴役状态（罕见，偏文学用法）

examples.en: The novel describes a community’s slow escape from enthralldom.
examples.zh: 这部小说描写了一个社区如何逐步摆脱奴役。

examples.en: He wrote about breaking the chains of enthralldom and reclaiming dignity.
examples.zh: 他写到挣脱奴役的枷锁、重拾尊严。

extraExplanation: “enthralldom”很少见，常见表达通常是“enthrallment”（着迷/沉醉）或“bondage / slavery / servitude”（奴役/束缚）。
词尾“-dom”表示“状态、领域、身份”（如 freedom, kingdom），所以“enthralldom”字面上就是“被 enthrall 的状态”。其中 enthrall 既可指“使着迷”，也可指“使成为奴隶/使受控制”，因此该词可在语境中呈现两层含义。

summary.en: Enthralled means completely fascinated or captivated; it can also be the past form of enthrall (to fascinate strongly).
summary.zh: enthralled 表示“深深着迷、被迷住”；也可作动词 enthrall 的过去式/过去分词，意为“使强烈着迷”。

definition.en: very interested and excited by something (so that you give it all your attention).
definition.zh: 被某事深深吸引、着迷（以至于全神贯注）。

examples.en: The audience was enthralled by her storytelling.
examples.zh: 观众被她的讲故事深深吸引。

examples.en: I was enthralled with the first chapter and kept reading late into the night.
examples.zh: 我被第一章迷住了，一直读到深夜。

definition.en: captured and held the attention of someone; fascinated someone.
definition.zh: 使（某人）着迷、吸引住；把（某人）的注意力牢牢抓住。

examples.en: The documentary enthralled viewers around the world.
examples.zh: 这部纪录片让全球观众都着迷。

examples.en: Her calm confidence enthralled the interview panel.
examples.zh: 她沉稳的自信吸引住了面试官。

extraExplanation: “enthralled”来自动词“enthrall”，词根与“thral(l)”（古英语里指“奴仆/受控制的人”）有关，所以它原本带有“被控制、被束缚”的感觉。现代英语里多用于比喻，表示“被某物强烈吸引到无法移开注意力”。
常见搭配：be enthralled by/with（被……迷住）；enthrall sb.（使某人着迷）。语气通常比“interested”更强，接近“fascinated/captivated”。

summary.en: An enthraller is a person or thing that strongly captivates people’s attention.
summary.zh: enthraller 指“使人强烈着迷的人或事物”。

definition.en: A person or thing that captivates and holds someone’s attention completely; someone or something that is very fascinating.
definition.zh: 使人着迷的人或事物；非常吸引人、让人目不转睛的东西。

examples.en: The singer was an enthraller; the audience fell silent and listened to every note.
examples.zh: 这位歌手非常引人入胜；观众安静下来，专注地听每一个音符。

examples.en: For many readers, the novel’s narrator becomes an enthraller who pulls you deeper into the story.
examples.zh: 对很多读者来说，这部小说的叙述者像个“迷人者”，把你一步步带进故事里。

extraExplanation: “enthraller”来自动词“enthrall”（使着迷、迷住）+ 后缀“-er”（做……的人/物），意思就是“使人着迷者”。在现代英语里它不算常用，更常见的表达是“a captivating person/thing”“a spellbinder”或直接用形容词“fascinating/captivating”。
“enthrall”早期与“thralldom（奴役、束缚）”有关，带有“被牢牢控制/抓住注意力”的隐喻色彩；现代多用于积极含义（被深深吸引）。

summary.en: Enthralling means extremely interesting or exciting, holding your full attention; it can also be the -ing form of “enthrall” (to fascinate).
summary.zh: enthralling 指“非常吸引人的、引人入胜的”；也可作动词 enthrall 的 -ing 形式，表示“使着迷”。

definition.en: Very interesting or exciting in a way that holds your attention completely; captivating.
definition.zh: 非常吸引人的；令人着迷的；引人入胜的。

examples.en: The movie was so enthralling that I forgot to check my phone.
examples.zh: 这部电影太引人入胜了，我都忘了看手机。

examples.en: She gave an enthralling talk about life in Antarctica.
examples.zh: 她做了一场关于南极生活的精彩演讲，令人着迷。

definition.en: Present participle of “enthrall,” meaning to capture someone’s attention completely; to fascinate.
definition.zh: “enthrall”的现在分词：使某人完全被吸引；使着迷。

examples.en: The storyteller kept enthralling the children with each new chapter.
examples.zh: 讲故事的人用每一章的新情节不断把孩子们迷住。

examples.en: Good teachers are skilled at enthralling a class without shouting.
examples.zh: 优秀的老师擅长在不大喊大叫的情况下吸引全班注意力。

extraExplanation: “enthrall”原义与“thral(l)”（古英语里“奴仆/被束缚的人”）相关，带有“把人牢牢控制住”的感觉。现代用法多为正面，强调“被精彩内容抓住注意力”。
学习区分：enthralling（让人着迷的，偏主动“吸引你”） vs. enthralled（你被迷住的，偏被动“你被吸引”）。例如：An enthralling book / I was enthralled by the book.
常见搭配：enthralling story/tale, enthralling performance, enthralling read；也常与“absolutely/truly”搭配加强语气。

summary.en: “Enthrallingly” means “in a captivating way that fully holds attention.”
summary.zh: “enthrallingly”意为“以极其引人入胜、牢牢抓住注意力的方式”。

definition.en: In a way that is so interesting, exciting, or beautiful that it holds your attention completely.
definition.zh: 以一种极其吸引人、令人兴奋或美丽的方式，让人目不转睛、完全被吸引。

examples.en: She spoke enthrallingly about her travels, and everyone listened in silence.
examples.zh: 她以非常吸引人的方式讲述旅行经历，大家都安静地听着。

examples.en: The documentary is enthrallingly made, with vivid scenes and clear storytelling.
examples.zh: 这部纪录片制作得很引人入胜，画面生动、叙事清晰。

examples.en: He plays the piano enthrallingly, making even beginners feel the emotion in the music.
examples.zh: 他钢琴弹得极其动人，让连初学者都能感受到音乐里的情绪。

extraExplanation: “enthrallingly”来自动词“enthrall”（使着迷、使完全投入），常用于较正式或文学化的语境，比“very interesting”更强调“被牢牢抓住注意力”的感觉。
常见搭配：enthrallingly told/interesting/beautiful；也常修饰故事、演讲、表演、书、电影等（an enthrallingly told story）。
近义表达可按强度选择：captivatingly（引人入胜地，较常用）、fascinatingly（令人着迷地）、spellbindingly（扣人心弦地，更偏文学）。

summary.en: Enthrallment means being (or making someone) deeply captivated and absorbed.
summary.zh: enthrallment 指（让人）深深着迷、全神贯注的状态或吸引力。

definition.en: A state of being completely captivated or fascinated; deep, enjoyable attention that holds you.
definition.zh: 着迷；入迷；被深深吸引的状态（注意力被牢牢抓住）。

examples.en: The audience watched in enthrallment as the magician revealed the final trick.
examples.zh: 魔术师揭晓最后一招时，观众看得入迷。

examples.en: She listened with quiet enthrallment to her grandfather’s stories.
examples.zh: 她安静地听着祖父的故事，听得津津有味、十分着迷。

definition.en: The act or power of enthralling someone—making them feel fully absorbed or captivated.
definition.zh: 使人着迷的行为或力量；让人完全投入、被吸引的过程。

examples.en: The film’s enthrallment comes from its music and strong characters.
examples.zh: 这部电影的“迷人之处”来自它的音乐和鲜明的人物。

examples.en: Good storytelling depends on the enthrallment of the listener.
examples.zh: 好的讲故事技巧取决于能否让听众被吸引、沉浸其中。

extraExplanation: 词源上与动词 enthrall 有关。enthraIl 原义与“置于束缚/奴役之中（thrall）”有关，所以 enthrallment 带有“被牢牢控制住注意力”的比喻色彩；现代常用于中性或褒义，表示“迷住、吸引住”。
语域：enthrallment 比 fascination 更正式、更带文学感；在影评、书评、演讲评价中常见。

summary.en: “Enthrallments” means strong fascinations or captivating things/experiences (plural).
summary.zh: “enthrallments”指强烈的着迷、迷恋，或令人着迷的事物/体验（复数）。

definition.en: strong fascination or deep interest that holds someone’s attention (plural of “enthrallment”)
definition.zh: 强烈的吸引力；使人着迷、目不转睛的状态（“enthrallment”的复数）

examples.en: The museum’s new exhibit offers many enthrallments for visitors of all ages.
examples.zh: 博物馆的新展览为各个年龄段的游客提供了许多令人着迷的看点。

examples.en: Her stories were full of small enthrallments—tiny details that kept us listening.
examples.zh: 她的故事充满了细小的迷人之处——那些小细节让我们一直听下去。

definition.en: things or experiences that captivate or charm people
definition.zh: 令人着迷的事物；迷人的体验

examples.en: City life has its enthrallments, but it can also be exhausting.
examples.zh: 城市生活有它迷人的地方，但也可能让人疲惫。

examples.en: For him, books were the greatest enthrallments in a quiet childhood.
examples.zh: 对他来说，书是安静童年里最令人着迷的事物。

extraExplanation: “enthrallment”来自动词“enthrall”（使着迷、迷住；也可指“奴役、束缚”这一较旧的含义）。现代英语里更常用的是“被迷住/入迷”的意思。
用法提示：日常口语更常说“fascination(s)”或“things that captivate me/us”。“enthrallment(s)”更偏书面、文学或评论类写作。

summary.en: “Enthralls” means (1) strongly fascinates or captivates someone, and (2) in a more formal/literary sense, holds someone in bondage or under control.
summary.zh: “enthralls”意为（1）使人着迷、深深吸引；（2）较正式/文学用法中指使受控制或奴役。

definition.en: to captivate or hold someone’s attention completely; to fascinate
definition.zh: 使着迷；迷住；牢牢吸引（某人的注意力）

examples.en: The movie enthralls audiences from the first scene to the last.
examples.zh: 这部电影从第一幕到最后一幕都让观众看得入迷。

examples.en: Her storytelling enthralls the children.
examples.zh: 她讲故事把孩子们迷得入神。

definition.en: to enslave or keep someone under another’s power (more formal or literary)
definition.zh: 使受奴役；使受控制（较正式或文学用法）

examples.en: In the legend, a dark spell enthralls the hero and steals his freedom.
examples.zh: 在传说中，黑暗的咒语奴役了英雄，夺走了他的自由。

examples.en: The novel shows how fear can enthrall an entire community.
examples.zh: 这部小说展现了恐惧如何控制整个社区。

extraExplanation: “enthralls”是动词“enthrall”的第三人称单数（he/she/it enthralls）。常见搭配：enthrall + someone；be enthralled by/with + something（如：I was enthralled by the music. 我被音乐迷住了）。
词源上与“in thrall（在束缚/奴役之中）”有关，所以除了“迷住”，也带有较文学的“控制、奴役”含义。

summary.en: Enthralment means a strong state of fascination or captivation; less commonly, it can mean being controlled or dominated.
summary.zh: enthralment 指强烈的着迷、沉醉；较少见时也可指被控制、被支配的状态。

definition.en: The state of being completely fascinated, captivated, or emotionally absorbed by someone or something.
definition.zh: 着迷；入迷；被深深吸引的状态。

examples.en: The enthralment of the audience was obvious—they barely blinked during the performance.
examples.zh: 观众的着迷显而易见——演出过程中他们几乎都不眨眼。

examples.en: She spoke about her enthralment with astronomy since childhood.
examples.zh: 她谈到自己从小就对天文学非常着迷。

definition.en: (Less common) The state of being held in control, like being “enslaved” or dominated by a power or influence.
definition.zh: （较少见）受控制、被支配的状态；类似“被奴役/束缚”。

examples.en: The novel explores his enthralment to ambition and the damage it causes.
examples.zh: 这部小说探讨了他被野心支配的状态以及它带来的伤害。

examples.en: They warned against the enthralment of citizens through fear and propaganda.
examples.zh: 他们警告不要让公民在恐惧与宣传中被控制。

extraExplanation: “enthralment”来自动词“enthral”（使人着迷/使人受制），与“thrall”（奴仆、受控的人）有关。所以它既可表示“迷住”（现代更常用），也可带有“受支配、被束缚”的较强含义（更文学化）。
美式英语里更常见的拼写是“enthrallment”（双l）；“enthralment”（单l）也可见，尤其在英式拼写或更文学的语境中。

summary.en: “Enthrals” means “captivates” or “holds completely,” and can also mean “brings under control” (often figuratively).
summary.zh: “enthrals”意为“使人着迷、深深吸引”，也可指（多为比喻）“控制、束缚”。

definition.en: (of a person, story, performance, etc.) to hold someone’s attention completely; to fascinate or captivate.
definition.zh: （人、故事、表演等）使人全神贯注；迷住；吸引住。

examples.en: The documentary enthrals viewers with real-life stories.
examples.zh: 这部纪录片用真实故事把观众深深吸引住。

examples.en: Her voice enthrals the audience from the first note.
examples.zh: 她的嗓音从第一个音符起就牢牢抓住了观众的注意力。

definition.en: to bring someone under your control in a way that limits freedom (often used figuratively).
definition.zh: （常为比喻）控制、束缚某人，使其失去自由。

examples.en: He became enthralled by power and ignored the people around him.
examples.zh: 他被权力所束缚（迷惑），忽视了身边的人。

examples.en: They felt enthralled to the system and unable to speak up.
examples.zh: 他们觉得被体制束缚，无法发声。

extraExplanation: “enthrals”多见于英式拼写（对应美式 enthralls）。两者意思相同，只是拼写习惯不同。
词根与古英语/古诺斯语中表示“奴仆、受奴役的人”的“thrall”有关，所以它既可以表示“迷住”（强烈吸引），也可以带有“束缚、控制”的比喻色彩。
常见搭配：be enthralled by/with（被……迷住/吸引）。例如：She was enthralled by the novel.（她被小说迷住了。）

summary.en: “Enthrill” means to captivate or greatly excite someone.
summary.zh: “enthrill”表示“使人着迷、非常兴奋”。

definition.en: to make someone feel very excited, interested, and pleased; to captivate
definition.zh: 使（某人）非常兴奋、着迷；迷住

examples.en: The movie’s special effects enthrilled the audience.
examples.zh: 这部电影的特效让观众着迷。

examples.en: She was enthrilled by the chance to study abroad.
examples.zh: 有机会出国学习让她兴奋不已。

examples.en: The story enthrilled readers with its surprising ending.
examples.zh: 这个故事用出人意料的结局让读者大呼过瘾。

definition.en: (less common) to thrill or excite; to feel thrilled
definition.zh: （较少用）使激动；感到激动

examples.en: Fans enthrilled at the sound of the band’s first song.
examples.zh: 乐队第一首歌响起时，粉丝们激动不已。

extraExplanation: “enthrill”常见于书面语或较正式的语境，日常口语里更常用“thrill / excite / captivate”。
词形提示：enthrill（动词）→ enthrilled（过去式/过去分词）→ enthrilling（现在分词/形容词用法，如“an enthrilling performance”）。

summary.en: Ent​hrone means to officially place a ruler on the throne, or (figuratively) to treat someone or something as the most important.
summary.zh: enthrone 指（正式）使君主登基，也可比喻把某人或某物奉为最重要、最高地位。

definition.en: to officially make someone a king, queen, or ruler by placing them on the throne (often in a formal ceremony)
definition.zh: （常指通过正式仪式）让某人成为国王/女王/统治者，使其登基

examples.en: The prince was enthroned after the death of his father.
examples.zh: 王子在父王去世后登基。

examples.en: She was enthroned in a ceremony attended by leaders from around the world.
examples.zh: 她在一场有世界各国领导人出席的仪式中登基。

definition.en: (figurative) to give someone or something the highest position or greatest importance
definition.zh: （比喻）把……奉为至高无上/最重要，使……居于最高地位

examples.en: The media sometimes enthrones celebrities as role models.
examples.zh: 媒体有时会把名人奉为榜样。

examples.en: In his mind, success was enthroned above everything else.
examples.zh: 在他心中，成功被置于一切之上。

extraExplanation: “enthrone”由“en-（使……处于……之中/使成为）+ throne（王座）”构成，字面意思就是“让某人坐上王座”。常见搭配：be enthroned（被加冕/登基）、enthrone a monarch（使君主登基）。
在新闻与历史语境里常见；比喻用法多用于批评或强调某种价值被“捧到最高”，语气有时带一点夸张或讽刺。

summary.en: “Enthroned” means placed on a throne or elevated to the highest status (literal or figurative).
summary.zh: “enthroned”指被推上王位或被抬到至高地位（可字面也可比喻）。

definition.en: Placed on a throne; made a king/queen or given a position of great power and honor.
definition.zh: 被立为君主的；被推上王位的；（引申）被赋予至高权力与尊荣的。

examples.en: After the old king died, the young prince was enthroned in a grand ceremony.
examples.zh: 老国王去世后，年轻的王子在盛大典礼上登基。

examples.en: In the painting, the goddess is enthroned above the crowd.
examples.zh: 在这幅画里，女神高坐于人群之上。

definition.en: Past form of “enthrone”: to place someone on a throne; to make someone a monarch (sometimes used figuratively).
definition.zh: “enthrone”的过去式/过去分词：使登基；让某人坐上王位；（比喻）把某人/某物奉为至高。

examples.en: The council enthroned her as queen to unite the country.
examples.zh: 议会拥立她为女王，以团结全国。

examples.en: Over time, the public enthroned the singer as a cultural icon.
examples.zh: 随着时间推移，大众把这位歌手奉为文化偶像。

extraExplanation: “enthroned”常见于新闻、历史书写与文学描写，语气较正式。比喻用法里，它不一定是真的“坐上王位”，而是强调“被推到最高、最受尊崇的位置”。
相关搭配：be enthroned as…（被立为……）；enthroned on/upon a throne（高坐在王座上）；enthrone someone as a hero/legend（把某人奉为英雄/传奇）。
词源提示：throne（王座）来自希腊语/拉丁语传统词形；en- 有“使……处于某状态”的意思，因此 enthrone = “使……坐上王座/成为君主”。

summary.en: Enthronement means the official ceremony of placing a monarch or high leader on a throne, and it can also mean (figuratively) making something the highest authority.
summary.zh: enthronement 指君主或高级领袖的登基/就任仪式；也可比喻把某人或某事抬到最高权威的地位。

definition.en: The formal ceremony of placing a king, queen, or other leader on a throne; the act of officially making someone a monarch or high religious leader.
definition.zh: （君主或宗教领袖的）登基/即位大典；正式加冕或就任的仪式。

examples.en: Millions watched the enthronement of the new king on live television.
examples.zh: 数百万人通过电视直播观看新国王的登基大典。

examples.en: The cathedral was filled for the archbishop’s enthronement.
examples.zh: 大教堂里挤满了人，参加新任大主教的就任仪式。

definition.en: Figuratively, the act of giving someone or something the highest power or status in a group or society.
definition.zh: （比喻）把某人或某事“捧上最高位”；让其成为主导或至高无上的存在。

examples.en: Some critics warned against the enthronement of profit over people.
examples.zh: 一些评论者警告不要把利润“供上神坛”，凌驾于民众之上。

examples.en: The novel shows the enthronement of tradition and the cost of change.
examples.zh: 这部小说展现了传统被奉为圭臬，以及改变所付出的代价。

extraExplanation: “enthronement”来自“throne（王座）”，字面意思是“放到王座上”。除了国王/女王的登基，也常用于宗教语境，如主教或大主教的“就座/就任”仪式。
比喻用法里，它常带有批评色彩，表示某种价值（如金钱、权力、名声）被抬到不应有的高度。
相关词：coronation（加冕，常用于君主），inauguration（就职，常用于民选领导人）。

summary.en: “Enthronements” is the plural of “enthronement,” meaning formal ceremonies of placing a ruler or religious leader on a throne, or (figuratively) putting someone or something in great power.
summary.zh: “enthronements”是“enthronement”的复数，指君主或宗教领袖的登基/就座典礼，也可比喻“让某人或某事物掌权、居于至高地位”。

definition.en: A formal ceremony in which a king, queen, or religious leader is placed on a throne and officially begins their rule or office.
definition.zh: 加冕／登基（或就座）典礼：把君主或宗教领袖安置在宝座上、正式开始统治或任职的仪式。

examples.en: Thousands of people gathered in the capital for the queen’s enthronement.
examples.zh: 成千上万的人聚集在首都参加女王的加冕典礼。

examples.en: The archbishop’s enthronement took place in the cathedral.
examples.zh: 大主教的就座典礼在大教堂举行。

definition.en: The act of putting someone in a position of great power or authority (often used figuratively).
definition.zh: （常作比喻）使某人登上高位、掌权：把某人推到极高权力或权威的位置。

examples.en: The party’s landslide victory led to the enthronement of a new leader.
examples.zh: 该党以压倒性胜利上台，使新领袖登上权力宝座。

examples.en: Some critics warned that celebrity culture can lead to the enthronement of fame over truth.
examples.zh: 一些批评者警告说，名人文化可能会让“名气”凌驾于真相之上。

extraExplanation: “enthronements”是名词复数，单数是“enthronement”。词根来自“throne（王座）”，加上前缀en-（使……处于某种状态），字面意思是“使坐上王座”。
在英国等君主制国家，相关典礼常见搭配是“coronation（加冕）”。一般来说，coronation强调戴上王冠；enthronement强调正式就座与被承认为统治者/职务开始。宗教语境里也常用enthronement（如主教在主教座堂的就座）。
文学或新闻中常用比喻义来表达“某种价值/观念被奉为至高”，例如“the enthronement of money”。

summary.en: “Enthrones” means officially placing someone on a throne, or (figuratively) giving someone/something supreme status.
summary.zh: “enthrones” 指使某人登基/加冕；也可比喻让某人或某事处于至高地位。

definition.en: to place someone on a throne; to make someone a king/queen or ruler officially (often in ceremonies)
definition.zh: 使某人登上王位；加冕为君主（常用于正式仪式）

examples.en: The council enthrones the new monarch in a public ceremony.
examples.zh: 议会在公开仪式上为新君主举行加冕。

examples.en: After the old king died, the prince was enthroned at the capital.
examples.zh: 老国王去世后，王子在首都登基。

definition.en: to give someone or something a position of great power, importance, or honor (often figurative)
definition.zh: （比喻）让某人或某事居于至高地位；奉为圭臬

examples.en: The company enthrones profit above everything else.
examples.zh: 这家公司把利润奉为至上。

examples.en: In some fan communities, a singer is quickly enthroned as a legend.
examples.zh: 在一些粉丝圈里，歌手很快就会被“封神”。

extraExplanation: “enthrones” 是动词 “enthrone” 的第三人称单数现在时（he/she/it enthrones）。过去式和过去分词是 “enthroned”。
这个词常见于历史、王室新闻或较正式的写作；日常口语里更常用 “crown” 表示“加冕”。比喻用法里，也常见 “enthrone A as B（把A奉为B）”。

summary.en: To enthrong means to crowd together or to fill a place with a large, dense group of people.
summary.zh: enthrong 意为“蜂拥聚集、挤满（某处）”，强调人很多、很拥挤。

definition.en: (of many people) to gather and fill a place in a crowded way; to crowd around something or someone.
definition.zh: （许多人）聚集并挤满某处；围拢在某物/某人周围。

examples.en: Fans enthronged the stadium hours before the concert began.
examples.zh: 演唱会开始前好几个小时，歌迷就挤满了体育场。

examples.en: Reporters enthronged around the actress as she left the courthouse.
examples.zh: 女演员离开法院时，记者们蜂拥围在她周围。

definition.en: to fill a place with a crowd (often used in passive forms).
definition.zh: 使某处挤满人群（常用于被动语态）。

examples.en: The streets were enthronged with holiday shoppers.
examples.zh: 街道上挤满了采购节日用品的人。

examples.en: The museum was enthronged during the free-admission weekend.
examples.zh: 免费开放的周末，博物馆里人山人海。

extraExplanation: “en-”有“使……处于某种状态/进入……”的意思；“throng”意为“人群、蜂拥的人”。因此“enthrong”整体带有“让某处成为拥挤的人群状态”的感觉。
这个词较偏书面语/新闻报道或文学描写中常见，用来强调“人潮涌动、围得水泄不通”的画面感。常见搭配：enthrong the streets / enthrong the entrance / be enthronged with people。

summary.en: “Enthroning” means installing a ruler on a throne (or, figuratively, putting someone/something in supreme power or importance).
summary.zh: “Enthroning”指让君主/领袖登基就位；也可比喻把某人或某事捧到最高权力或最重要的位置。

definition.en: the act of placing a king, queen, or religious leader on a throne; officially crowning or installing them as a ruler/leader
definition.zh: 使君主或宗教领袖登基就位；正式加冕或任命其为统治者/领袖

examples.en: The enthroning of the new king drew crowds from across the country.
examples.zh: 新国王的登基大典吸引了全国各地的人群。

examples.en: After the ceremony of enthroning, the queen gave her first public speech.
examples.zh: 登基仪式结束后，女王发表了她的首次公开演讲。

definition.en: (figurative) the act of giving someone or something the highest power, honor, or importance
definition.zh: （比喻）将某人或某事奉为最高权威/最重要的地位

examples.en: The novel warns against the enthroning of money above human dignity.
examples.zh: 这部小说警示人们不要把金钱奉为高于人类尊严的最高价值。

examples.en: In his speeches, he criticized the enthroning of celebrity culture in daily life.
examples.zh: 在演讲中，他批评日常生活中对名人文化的推崇至上。

definition.en: present participle of “enthrone”; describing the action of placing someone in a position of rule or supreme importance
definition.zh: “enthrone”的现在分词；表示正在使某人登基或把某事置于至高地位的动作

examples.en: They are enthroning a new leader after months of debate.
examples.zh: 经过数月争论，他们正拥立一位新领袖。

examples.en: The film shows a society enthroning technology as the answer to everything.
examples.zh: 这部电影展示了一个把科技奉为万能答案的社会。

extraExplanation: “enthroning”既可作名词（表示“登基/加冕这一行为”），也可作动词形式（现在分词），常出现在进行时或作定语：e.g., “an enthroning ceremony”（登基仪式）。
字面义多用于君主制或宗教传统（如主教就任），比喻义在评论性写作中很常见，用来批评或强调某种价值/人物被“捧上神坛”。

summary.en: To enthronise is to install a ruler (or leader) in power, often by a formal ceremony, or to establish someone firmly in authority.
summary.zh: enthronise 指（常通过正式仪式）使君主登基或使某人就任，也可引申为“使某人稳坐权位/确立权威”。

definition.en: (BrE) to place a king, queen, or other leader in an official position of power, especially in a formal ceremony; to establish someone firmly in a position of authority.
definition.zh: （英式）使（国王、女王等）登基；（尤指通过正式仪式）使就任；也可引申为“使稳坐某个权力/权威位置”。

examples.en: The new king was enthronised in a ceremony watched by millions.
examples.zh: 新国王在数百万人观看的仪式中登基。

examples.en: After years of internal conflict, the party finally enthronised a new leader.
examples.zh: 经历多年内斗后，该党终于让一位新领导人正式上台。

extraExplanation: “enthronise”更常见于英式拼写；美式通常写作“enthronize”。两者意思相同。
词源和“throne（王座）”直接相关：en-（使…）+ throne（王座），字面意思就是“把某人放上王座”。
语体偏正式，多用于君主制、宗教或历史语境；引申义常用于政治、机构或观念（如“enthrone an idea”=把某种观念奉为主导）。

summary.en: Enthronised means officially made a king/queen (or, figuratively, raised to top status).
summary.zh: enthronised 指被正式立为君主（或比喻被推到至高地位）。

definition.en: (Especially in British English) Officially placed on the throne; crowned and made king or queen.
definition.zh: （尤用于英式英语）被正式扶上王位的；加冕为国王或女王的。

examples.en: The new monarch was enthronised in a grand ceremony at the cathedral.
examples.zh: 新君主在大教堂举行的盛大仪式中登基加冕。

examples.en: After she was enthronised, she gave her first speech to the nation.
examples.zh: 她登基后，向全国发表了第一次讲话。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of enthronise: to place someone in a position of supreme power or high status (sometimes used figuratively).
definition.zh: enthronise 的过去式/过去分词：使某人登上王位；（也可比喻）把某人推到至高权力或崇高地位上。

examples.en: He was enthronised as the leader of the party after the election.
examples.zh: 选举后，他被推举为该党领袖。

examples.en: Some critics say the media has enthronised celebrity culture.
examples.zh: 一些评论家说媒体把名人文化捧上了“宝座”。

extraExplanation: “enthronised”更常见于英式拼写；美式常写作 enthroned。两者意思相同。
字面意思是“放到王座上”，因此既可用于君主登基，也常用于比喻语境：把某种观念、制度或人物“奉为至高”。
常见搭配：be enthronised at/in…（在某地举行登基仪式）；figuratively: enthronise/enthrone someone/something as…（把……捧为/奉为……）。

summary.en: “Enthronising” means formally placing someone on a throne or installing them as an official leader (also used for installing a bishop in a cathedral).
summary.zh: “enthronising”指让某人正式登基或就任为正式领导者（也可指主教在主教座堂的安座就任）。

definition.en: (present participle of “enthronize”) the act of placing someone on a throne; formally making someone a king/queen or other official leader.
definition.zh: （“enthronize”的现在分词）使某人登基；正式立某人为国王/女王或其他正式领导者的行为。

examples.en: The ceremony is about enthronising the new monarch.
examples.zh: 这场仪式是为了让新君主登基。

examples.en: They celebrated the enthronising of their leader with speeches and music.
examples.zh: 他们用演讲和音乐庆祝领袖就任（登位）。

definition.en: In some Christian churches, formally installing a bishop or archbishop in their official seat (cathedra) in a cathedral.
definition.zh: （在一些基督教教会中）在主教座堂把主教/大主教正式安置在其主教座（cathedra）上，表示就任。

examples.en: The cathedral hosted the enthronising of the new bishop.
examples.zh: 主教座堂举行了新主教的就任（安座）仪式。

examples.en: After the enthronising, the bishop gave a short blessing.
examples.zh: 安座仪式后，主教做了简短的祝福。

extraExplanation: “enthronising”是英式拼写；美式常写作“enthronizing”。两者意思相同。
这个词通常出现在较正式、仪式感强的语境（王室加冕/登基、宗教就任仪式），日常口语更常用“put someone in power / install a leader”等说法（语气更中性或更口语）。

summary.en: Enthronization means the official ceremony of placing a ruler on the throne, or (figuratively) making someone/something supremely important.
summary.zh: enthronization 指君主（或领袖）登基/即位的正式典礼；也可比喻把某人或某种价值“捧上最高位置”。

definition.en: the ceremony of placing a king/queen or other leader on a throne; the official start of their rule
definition.zh: 登基/即位仪式；正式开始统治的典礼

examples.en: The enthronization of the new king was broadcast on national television.
examples.zh: 新国王的登基仪式在国家电视台直播。

examples.en: Thousands gathered in the capital for the enthronization ceremony.
examples.zh: 成千上万的人聚集在首都参加登基典礼。

examples.en: In some traditions, the enthronization includes an oath to serve the people.
examples.zh: 在一些传统中，登基仪式包含为人民服务的宣誓。

definition.en: the act of giving someone great power, status, or importance (often used figuratively)
definition.zh: （常作比喻）使某人拥有至高权力/地位；将某事“奉为圭臬”

examples.en: The enthronization of celebrity culture changed how people value success.
examples.zh: 对名人文化的“奉为圭臬”改变了人们衡量成功的方式。

examples.en: Critics warned against the enthronization of profit over public health.
examples.zh: 批评者警告不要把利润置于公共健康之上。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：来自 en-（使……处于某种状态）+ throne（王座）+ -ization（名词后缀），字面意思是“让某人坐上王座”。
使用场景：在英语新闻里，en-throne（动词）更常见；enthronization 多见于正式报道、历史写作或宗教语境（如主教的就座仪式）。
文学/文化用法：在写作中常用于比喻，把某种观念或价值“捧上王座”，强调它被过度崇拜或被置于最高地位。

summary.en: Enthronize means to install a monarch on the throne (literally) or to place someone/something in the highest position (figuratively).
summary.zh: enthronize 指（字面）为君主举行登基仪式，或（比喻）把某人/某事奉为最高、最重要的地位。

definition.en: to make someone a king/queen or other monarch in a formal ceremony; to place on the throne
definition.zh: （通过正式仪式）使某人成为君主；让……登基

examples.en: The prince was enthronized in a grand ceremony at the cathedral.
examples.zh: 王子在大教堂举行的盛大仪式上登基。

examples.en: After the coronation, the new queen was formally enthronized before the court.
examples.zh: 加冕之后，新女王在朝臣面前正式登基。

definition.en: (figurative) to give someone or something the highest position, authority, or importance
definition.zh: （比喻）把……奉为至高无上；让……占据最高地位

examples.en: Some people enthronize money above family and health.
examples.zh: 有些人把金钱奉为高于家庭和健康的一切。

examples.en: The story enthronizes courage as the greatest virtue.
examples.zh: 这个故事把勇气奉为最重要的美德。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：en-（使……处于某种状态）+ throne（王座）。这个词常见于历史、宗教或王室语境（如登基、就座于主教座位），也可用于比喻表达“把某事/某人抬到最高地位”。
用法提醒：更常见的说法是 enthrone；enthronize 相对更正式、也更少见，多出现在书面语或历史叙述中。

summary.en: “Enthronized” means officially installed as a ruler/leader, or (figuratively) firmly established as supreme.
summary.zh: “enthronized”指被正式加冕/立为领袖；也可比喻某人或观念被确立为至高无上。

definition.en: Formally made a king, queen, or religious leader; installed in a position of highest authority.
definition.zh: 被正式加冕为君主或被立为宗教领袖；被安置在最高权位上。

examples.en: The young prince was enthronized after his father’s death.
examples.zh: 老国王去世后，这位年轻的王子被正式加冕。

examples.en: The new patriarch was enthronized in a ceremony attended by thousands.
examples.zh: 新任宗主教在数千人出席的典礼中被正式就任。

definition.en: Placed or established firmly as the most powerful or most respected person or idea.
definition.zh: （比喻）被确立为最有权势或最受推崇的人或观念。

examples.en: Over time, the policy became enthronized as the “only sensible choice.”
examples.zh: 随着时间推移，这项政策被奉为“唯一合理的选择”。

examples.en: In the company culture, speed is enthronized above careful planning.
examples.zh: 在这家公司的文化里，速度被捧得比周密计划更重要。

extraExplanation: “enthronized”来自动词“enthronize”，核心意象是把某人“放到王座（throne）上”。既可指真实的加冕/就任仪式，也常用于写作中的比喻，表示某种人或价值被“奉为至高”。
相关词：throne（王座/王权），enthrone（使登上王位/使处于至高地位），enthronement（加冕/就任典礼）。
在新闻与历史写作中常见于宗教语境（如主教、宗主教的就任）以及君主制国家的加冕场景。

summary.en: Entbronizing means officially placing a ruler on the throne, or figuratively elevating someone to a powerful, almost “royal” status.
summary.zh: enthronizing 指让统治者正式登上王位（加冕/登基），也可比喻把某人捧到极高的权力或地位。

definition.en: (Present participle) putting a king, queen, or other leader onto a throne; officially installing them as ruler.
definition.zh: （现在分词）让国王、女王或其他领袖登上王位；正式为其举行即位/登基仪式。

examples.en: The country celebrated for a week during the enthronizing of the new king.
examples.zh: 新国王的登基期间，全国庆祝了一周。

examples.en: The ceremony focused on tradition, music, and the enthronizing moment itself.
examples.zh: 仪式聚焦于传统、音乐以及真正“加冕/登基”的那一刻。

definition.en: (Figurative) placing someone in a position of great power or importance; treating someone as if they rule.
definition.zh: （比喻）把某人推到极高的权力或重要地位；把某人捧得像“统治者”一样。

examples.en: By always praising him and never questioning him, they were enthronizing him in the group.
examples.zh: 他们总是夸他、从不质疑他，等于把他在团队里“捧上了王座”。

examples.en: The media can end up enthronizing celebrities as moral authorities.
examples.zh: 媒体有时会把名人捧成“道德权威”。

extraExplanation: “enthronizing”来自动词“enthrone”，语体偏正式，多用于君主制国家、宗教场合（如主教就任的典礼也可用“enthronement”）。日常英语里更常见名词“enthronement”（即位/登基典礼）或动词“enthrone/enthroned”。
在比喻用法中，它常带一点批评意味：暗示过度吹捧、把某人抬得过高。

summary.en: Enthuse means to show or express strong excitement and interest, often by talking enthusiastically about something.
summary.zh: Enthuse 指对某事表现或表达强烈的兴奋和兴趣，常通过热情地谈论来体现。

definition.en: to show or express strong excitement and interest about something; to speak in an enthusiastic way
definition.zh: 对某事表现出（或表达）强烈的兴奋与兴趣；热情地谈论

examples.en: She enthused about the new project and couldn’t stop smiling.
examples.zh: 她兴奋地谈论新项目，笑个不停。

examples.en: He enthused that the movie was the best he’d seen all year.
examples.zh: 他激动地说那部电影是他今年看过最棒的一部。

extraExplanation: “Enthuse”在口语和写作中都常见，语气较积极，常用于“enthuse about/over + 事物”或“enthuse that + 从句”。
相关词：enthusiasm（名词：热情）、enthusiastic（形容词：热情的）、enthusiast（名词：爱好者）。

summary.en: “Enthused” means excited and enthusiastic; it can also be the past form of “enthuse” (to speak with enthusiasm).
summary.zh: “Enthused”表示“兴奋、热情的”；也可作动词“enthuse”的过去式/过去分词，指“热情地谈论或称赞”。

definition.en: Feeling excited, interested, and full of positive energy about something.
definition.zh: 对某事感到兴奋、很感兴趣、充满热情的。

examples.en: She was enthused about the chance to study abroad.
examples.zh: 她对出国留学的机会感到很兴奋。

examples.en: The students sounded enthused after the science show.
examples.zh: 科学表演结束后，学生们听起来很激动、很有兴趣。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “enthuse”: to show or express enthusiastic interest or praise.
definition.zh: “enthuse”的过去式/过去分词：表现或表达热情的兴趣或称赞。

examples.en: He enthused about the new restaurant to all his friends.
examples.zh: 他向所有朋友热情地夸赞那家新餐厅。

examples.en: The coach enthused over the team’s progress.
examples.zh: 教练热情地称赞球队的进步。

extraExplanation:
“Enthused”常见两种用法：
1) 形容词：be enthused about + 名词/动名词（最常见）。例如：I’m enthused about starting a new job.
2) 动词：enthused about/over + 事物，语气比较书面或强调“热情地谈论/称赞”。日常口语里更常用：be excited / be enthusiastic / rave about。

注意拼写与语气：
- enthused（热情兴奋）通常偏积极、外露；
- interested（感兴趣）更中性、强度更弱。

summary.en: “Enthuses” means “speaks or writes enthusiastically (about/over something).”
summary.zh: “enthuses”表示“热情地谈论/称赞（某事）”。

definition.en: (present tense, 3rd-person singular of “enthuse”) to speak or write with great excitement and positive energy about something.
definition.zh: （“enthuse”的第三人称单数）热情地谈论或写某事；兴奋地称赞某事。

examples.en: She enthuses about the new project whenever she talks to the team.
examples.zh: 她每次和团队聊起新项目都兴致勃勃。

examples.en: He enthuses in his blog about how the book changed his thinking.
examples.zh: 他在博客里热情地写到那本书如何改变了他的想法。

examples.en: My dad always enthuses over good coffee.
examples.zh: 我爸总是对好咖啡赞不绝口。

extraExplanation: “enthuse”常见搭配：enthuse about + 话题（热情谈论），enthuse over + 事物（对……赞不绝口）。
语气通常是正面、带感染力的；在较正式的写作中，也可用更中性的表达如 “praise” 或 “speak highly of”。

summary.en: Enthusiasm means strong excitement and eager interest, often shown through energetic support.
summary.zh: Enthusiasm 指强烈的兴奋与热情，常表现为积极投入和热烈支持。

definition.en: A strong feeling of excitement, interest, and eager energy about something.
definition.zh: 对某事强烈的兴奋、兴趣与热情（积极想投入的劲头）。

examples.en: She spoke about the project with real enthusiasm.
examples.zh: 她谈起这个项目时充满真挚的热情。

examples.en: The students showed enthusiasm for the new club.
examples.zh: 学生们对这个新社团表现出热情。

definition.en: Warm approval and active support for an idea, plan, or activity.
definition.zh: 对某个想法、计划或活动的热烈赞同与积极支持。

examples.en: The proposal was met with enthusiasm from the team.
examples.zh: 这个提案得到了团队的热烈支持。

examples.en: Her enthusiasm helped others feel more confident.
examples.zh: 她的热情让其他人更有信心。

extraExplanation: “enthusiasm”常与介词搭配：enthusiasm for（对……的热情），enthusiasm about（对……感到兴奋/热情）。例如：enthusiasm for learning（对学习的热情）。
词源上与希腊语中“inspired/possessed by a god（受神启发）”相关，所以在文学语境里它有时带一点“灵感迸发、热情洋溢”的色彩。现代日常英语里通常就是“热情/积极劲儿”，不带宗教含义。

summary.en: “Enthusiasms” is the plural of “enthusiasm,” meaning strong excitement and interest, or a person’s different passions.
summary.zh: “enthusiasms”是“enthusiasm”的复数，表示强烈的热情/兴奋与兴趣，也可指一个人多方面的热爱与兴趣。

definition.en: Strong excitement and eager interest (often about an activity, idea, or plan).
definition.zh: （对某活动、想法或计划的）热情；热忱；强烈的兴趣与兴奋。

examples.en: Her enthusiasm for learning English helped her practice every day.
examples.zh: 她对学习英语的热情让她每天都坚持练习。

examples.en: The team showed real enthusiasm during the project meeting.
examples.zh: 团队在项目会议上表现出真正的热情。

definition.en: (Plural) Different strong interests or passions that a person has.
definition.zh: （复数）一个人拥有的多种热爱与兴趣；多方面的“热情点”。

examples.en: His enthusiasms include cooking, hiking, and jazz music.
examples.zh: 他热爱的事情包括做饭、徒步和爵士乐。

examples.en: She spoke about her enthusiasms with energy and confidence.
examples.zh: 她充满活力、自信地谈起自己的各种热爱。

extraExplanation: “enthusiasm”本身通常是不可数名词，表示抽象的“热情”；但在谈“不同类型的热情/兴趣”时，可以用复数“enthusiasms”（如：his enthusiasms）。
词源来自希腊语，原意与“受神启发”有关，因此它常带有“被某种想法点燃、充满动力”的感觉。
常见搭配：enthusiasm for (something)（对……的热情）；show enthusiasm（表现出热情）；with enthusiasm（热情地）。

summary.en: An enthusiast is someone who is very interested in and excited about a particular hobby, topic, or cause.
summary.zh: enthusiast 指对某个爱好、主题或事业非常感兴趣、充满热情的人（爱好者/热心支持者）。

definition.en: A person who is very interested in a particular activity, subject, or hobby and enjoys learning more about it.
definition.zh: （对某项活动、主题或爱好）非常感兴趣并乐于深入了解的人；爱好者。

examples.en: She’s a photography enthusiast who spends weekends taking pictures of birds.
examples.zh: 她是摄影爱好者，周末常去拍鸟。

examples.en: Car enthusiasts gathered to see the newest models.
examples.zh: 汽车爱好者聚在一起看最新款车型。

definition.en: A person who shows strong excitement and support for something (often an idea, project, or cause).
definition.zh: （对某个想法、项目或事业）充满热情并积极支持的人。

examples.en: Early enthusiasts helped the app grow by telling their friends.
examples.zh: 早期的热心支持者通过推荐给朋友帮助这款应用发展起来。

examples.en: He’s an enthusiastic supporter—an enthusiast for community gardening.
examples.zh: 他是非常热心的支持者，是社区园艺的倡导者/爱好者。

extraExplanation: “enthusiast”来自希腊语词根，原意与“被神灵激发/充满灵感”有关；现代英语里多用来表示对某事“热爱、投入”。

易混词：
- enthusiast（名词，人）：a music enthusiast 音乐爱好者
- enthusiastic（形容词，状态）：She is enthusiastic about music. 她对音乐很热情
- enthusiasm（名词，情绪/热情）：His enthusiasm is contagious. 他的热情很有感染力
语气与场景：在日常英语里，“enthusiast”通常是中性或褒义，常用于兴趣圈（sports/tech/food 等）或支持者群体（early enthusiasts）。

summary.en: “Enthusiastic” means very excited and eager, showing strong positive interest or support.
summary.zh: “enthusiastic” 表示非常兴奋、积极投入，对某事抱有强烈的正面兴趣或支持。

definition.en: Showing strong interest, excitement, or eager support for something.
definition.zh: 对某事表现出强烈兴趣、兴奋或热切支持的；热情的。

examples.en: She’s enthusiastic about learning English, so she practices every day.
examples.zh: 她对学英语很热情，所以每天都练习。

examples.en: The audience gave an enthusiastic response to the singer’s new song.
examples.zh: 观众对歌手的新歌反应热烈。

extraExplanation: 词形变化：enthusiasm（n. 热情）；enthusiast（n. 爱好者/热心人）。常见搭配：be enthusiastic about (doing) sth（对……很热情）；an enthusiastic supporter（热心的支持者）。
语气对比：enthusiastic 比 interested（感兴趣）更强烈、更外显；比 excited（兴奋）更偏“积极支持/投入”，不一定是短暂情绪。

summary.en: Enthusiastical is an archaic/literary word meaning “enthusiastic,” sometimes implying excessive enthusiasm.
summary.zh: Enthusiastical 是较古旧/文学性的词，意为“热情的、充满兴趣的”，有时也可暗示“热情过度”。

definition.en: (Archaic or literary) full of enthusiasm; very excited and interested.
definition.zh: （古旧或文学用语）充满热情的；非常兴奋、非常感兴趣的。

examples.en: She wrote an enthusiastical letter about the concert.
examples.zh: 她写了一封充满热情的信，谈论那场音乐会。

examples.en: His enthusiastical support helped the team stay confident.
examples.zh: 他热情洋溢的支持帮助团队保持信心。

definition.en: (Less common) showing excessive or overly emotional enthusiasm; sometimes close to “fanatical.”
definition.zh: （较少见）热情过度的；情绪化地狂热的（有时接近“狂热的/盲目的”）。

examples.en: The speech attracted some enthusiastical followers who accepted every claim without question.
examples.zh: 那场演讲吸引了一些过度狂热的追随者，他们对每个说法都不加质疑。

extraExplanation: “enthusiastical”在现代英语里比较少见，多见于较早的文本或带有复古/文学色彩的写作中。日常表达通常用“enthusiastic”。
词尾“-ical”常把名词或形容词变成“……性质的/……风格的”，因此“enthusiastical”字面上有“具有热情特征的”之意。
因为它听起来偏古典或夸张，在现代写作中使用时可能带一点修辞效果；如果你想表达中性、自然的语气，优先选“enthusiastic”。

summary.en: “Enthusiastically” means doing something with strong excitement, eagerness, and positive energy.
summary.zh: “enthusiastically”表示“带着强烈的兴奋、热情和积极劲头去做某事”。

definition.en: In a very excited, eager, and positive way; showing strong interest or energy.
definition.zh: 热情地；兴奋而积极地；表现出强烈兴趣或活力地。

examples.en: She spoke enthusiastically about her new job.
examples.zh: 她热情地谈起了她的新工作。

examples.en: The students enthusiastically joined the discussion.
examples.zh: 学生们热情地参与了讨论。

examples.en: He accepted the invitation enthusiastically.
examples.zh: 他欣然（热情地）接受了邀请。

extraExplanation: “enthusiastically”来自“enthusiastic（热情的）+ -ally（副词后缀）”。在语气上比“happily（开心地）”更强调“投入、兴奋、积极参与”。
常见搭配：enthusiastically agree（热烈赞同）、enthusiastically support（积极支持）、enthusiastically recommend（强烈推荐）、enthusiastically participate（踊跃参加）。
近义词对比：eagerly（急切地，想要得到/做到）、excitedly（兴奋地，情绪起伏更明显）、passionately（充满激情地，带更强烈的情感或立场）。

summary.en: A rare, nonstandard noun meaning “the state of being very enthusiastic.”
summary.zh: 一个罕见且非标准的名词，意为“非常热情/兴奋的状态”。

definition.en: The quality or state of being highly enthusiastic; intense eagerness or excitement (rare, nonstandard).
definition.zh: （罕见、非标准用法）极度热情/兴奋的状态；热忱之感。

examples.en: Her enthusiasticalness about the new project was contagious.
examples.zh: 她对新项目的那股极度热情很有感染力。

examples.en: The speech was full of youthful enthusiasticalness.
examples.zh: 这场演讲充满了年轻人的热忱与激动。

extraExplanation: “enthusiasticalness”是由形容词“enthusiastical（热情的）”加名词后缀“-ness（……的状态/性质）”构成的派生词，但在现代英语中非常少见，很多情况下会被认为不够自然。更常用、更地道的表达是“enthusiasm（热情）”或“eagerness（渴望）”。
在正式写作或考试中建议避免使用该词；如果你想表达“热情的特质”，可选“enthusiasm”“zeal”“excitement”。如果想表达“对某事很热衷”，可用短语“be enthusiastic about …”。

summary.en: “Enthusiastly” is nonstandard; use “enthusiastically” meaning “with enthusiasm.”
summary.zh: “enthusiastly”是不规范用法；应使用“enthusiastically”，意思是“热情地/兴致勃勃地”。

definition.en: (Nonstandard) Intended to mean “in an enthusiastic way,” but this form is not commonly used in modern English. The standard adverb is “enthusiastically.”
definition.zh: （不规范用法）想表达“以热情的方式”，但这个形式在现代英语中不常用。标准副词是“enthusiastically（热情地）”。

examples.en: Incorrect: She spoke enthusiastly about the project.
examples.zh: 错误：她用 enthusiastly 热情地谈论这个项目。

examples.en: Correct: She spoke enthusiastically about the project.
examples.zh: 正确：她热情地谈论这个项目。

definition.en: Enthusiastically; with strong interest, excitement, or eagerness.
definition.zh: 热情地；兴致勃勃地；带着强烈兴趣、兴奋或渴望地。

examples.en: The fans cheered enthusiastically when the band came on stage.
examples.zh: 乐队上台时，粉丝们热情地欢呼。

examples.en: He enthusiastically volunteered to help organize the event.
examples.zh: 他非常积极地自愿帮忙组织活动。

examples.en: She nodded enthusiastically, eager to learn more.
examples.zh: 她热情地点头，渴望了解更多。

extraExplanation: “enthusiastly”在日常英语、写作和词典中都很少见，通常会被认为是拼写或构词错误。建议在正式与非正式场合都使用“enthusiastically”。
构词提示：enthusiastic（形容词）+ -ally（副词后缀）→ enthusiastically。很多以 -ic 结尾的形容词变副词时用 -ically（如 basic→basically, dramatic→dramatically）。

summary.en: Enthusiasts are people who are very excited about a hobby, topic, or idea; the word is the plural of enthusiast.
summary.zh: enthusiasts 指对某项爱好、话题或理念非常热情的人；为 enthusiast 的复数。

definition.en: People who are very interested in a particular activity, topic, or hobby and feel excited about it.
definition.zh: 对某项活动、话题或爱好非常感兴趣并充满热情的人；爱好者；发烧友。

examples.en: Car enthusiasts gathered to show off their classic vehicles.
examples.zh: 汽车爱好者聚在一起展示他们的经典车型。

examples.en: The museum offers special events for history enthusiasts.
examples.zh: 博物馆为历史爱好者提供特别活动。

examples.en: She’s a fitness enthusiast who runs every morning.
examples.zh: 她是个健身爱好者，每天早上都跑步。

definition.en: A person who strongly supports an idea or project and promotes it with energy.
definition.zh: 热情支持并积极推动某个想法或项目的人；拥护者。

examples.en: Early enthusiasts of the new app helped spread the word online.
examples.zh: 这款新应用的早期拥护者在网上帮忙宣传。

examples.en: He’s an enthusiast for public libraries and community learning.
examples.zh: 他热心支持公共图书馆和社区学习。

extraExplanation: “enthusiast”来自希腊语，原意与“被神灵感动、充满灵感”有关。现代英语里多指对某事很有热情的人，语气通常积极。
常见搭配：sports enthusiasts（运动爱好者）、tech enthusiasts（科技发烧友）、enthusiast community（爱好者社群）。注意：enthusiasts 是复数；单数是 enthusiast。

summary.en: “Enthusing” means talking or writing about something with excited admiration.
summary.zh: “enthusing”表示带着兴奋与赞赏去谈论或写作某事，热情称赞。

definition.en: To speak or write with strong excitement and admiration about something; to praise enthusiastically.
definition.zh: 充满兴奋与赞赏地谈论或写作某事；热情称赞。

examples.en: She was enthusing about the new restaurant she tried last weekend.
examples.zh: 她兴致勃勃地夸赞上周末去过的新餐厅。

examples.en: He kept enthusing over the movie’s soundtrack on the way home.
examples.zh: 回家的路上他一直在热情称赞那部电影的配乐。

extraExplanation: “enthusing”来自动词“enthuse”，意思是“热情谈论/称赞”。在英语里，常见搭配是：enthuse about（热情谈论……）、enthuse over（对……赞不绝口）。
语气通常偏积极、带感染力；和“brag（吹嘘）”不同，“enthuse”强调真诚的喜欢与兴奋，而不是自夸。

summary.en: Enthymematic describes an argument that leaves a premise unstated for the audience to infer.
summary.zh: enthymematic 指“省略三段论式的”论证：省略一个前提，让听众自行补全。

definition.en: Relating to an enthymeme—a common kind of argument that leaves one premise unstated because the speaker assumes the audience will supply it.
definition.zh: 与“省略三段论（enthymeme）”有关的；指一种论证方式把某个前提省略不说，因为说话者假定听众会自行补上。

examples.en: The ad’s reasoning is enthymematic: it never says the product is safe, but it expects viewers to assume it is.
examples.zh: 这则广告的推理是省略三段论式的：它没有明说产品“安全”，却指望观众自行认为它安全。

examples.en: Her speech used enthymematic logic to persuade the crowd without spelling out every step.
examples.zh: 她的演讲运用了省略三段论式的逻辑来打动人群，而不把每一步都说得很清楚。

extraExplanation: “enthymematic”来自“enthymeme（省略三段论）”。在修辞学与批判性思维里，它常用来分析演讲、广告、社论等：通过省略某个“大家都同意”的前提，让论证听起来更自然、更有说服力，但也更容易把有争议的假设藏起来。
常见识别方法：问一句“要让这个结论成立，还缺了哪条前提？”缺的那条往往就是被默认的前提。
相关背景：这一概念常与亚里士多德（Aristotle）的修辞学讨论联系在一起。

summary.en: “Enthymematical” means “based on or involving an enthymeme,” a persuasive argument with an unstated premise.
summary.zh: “enthymematical”指“省略三段论式的”，即包含未明说前提的说服性论证。

definition.en: Relating to an enthymeme: a rhetorical argument in which one premise is implied rather than stated.
definition.zh: （与）省略三段论有关的：一种修辞论证方式，其中一个前提不明说而是默认/暗示。

examples.en: The columnist used an enthymematical argument, assuming readers already agreed with the unstated premise.
examples.zh: 这位专栏作者用了省略三段论式的论证，默认读者已经同意那个未明说的前提。

examples.en: In debate class, we learned to identify enthymematical reasoning by asking, “What assumption is missing?”
examples.zh: 在辩论课上，我们学习通过追问“缺失了什么假设？”来识别省略三段论式推理。

extraExplanation: “Enthymematical”比较少见，更常见的相关词是“enthymeme”（省略三段论）和“enthymematic”（同义形容词）。
省略三段论常用于演讲、广告、政治论述等场景：通过省略一个“大家都认同”的前提，让论证更简洁、更有说服力，但也更容易隐藏有争议的假设。
例：‘He’s a good father—he works hard.’ 省略的前提可能是‘努力工作的人就是好父亲’。识别这种省略有助于批判性阅读与思辨。

summary.en: An enthymeme is a persuasive argument that leaves an important premise unstated, relying on the audience to fill it in.
summary.zh: enthymeme 指“省略三段论”：论证中省略关键前提，依靠听众自行补全，从而达到说服效果。

definition.en: A rhetorical argument in which one premise is not stated because it is assumed or understood by the audience.
definition.zh: 省略三段论：一种修辞论证方式，其中有一个前提不明说，而是默认听众会理解或同意。

examples.en: “She’s honest—she wouldn’t lie to us.” (The unstated premise is that honest people don’t lie.)
examples.zh: “她很诚实——不会对我们撒谎。”（省略的前提是：诚实的人不会撒谎。）

examples.en: In many ads, an enthymeme works because the audience quickly supplies the missing step.
examples.zh: 在很多广告里，省略三段论之所以有效，是因为观众会很快把缺失的推理步骤补上。

definition.en: A shortened or informal syllogism (a logical argument) that leaves out a premise or the conclusion.
definition.zh: 一种被简化的三段论（逻辑论证），省略了某个前提或结论。

examples.en: The speaker used an enthymeme instead of a fully stated syllogism to sound more natural.
examples.zh: 演讲者用省略三段论而不是完整的三段论，让表达听起来更自然。

examples.en: To test the argument, write the missing premise and see whether it is actually true.
examples.zh: 要检验这个论证，把省略的前提写出来，看看它是否真的成立。

extraExplanation: “enthymeme”常见于修辞学与批判性思维课程，特别是在分析政治演讲、广告文案、社交媒体观点时很有用：它提醒我们注意“没说出口但被默认”的前提。
词源来自希腊语，含“在心中/在脑中”的意思，暗示省略的部分是让听众自己在心里补全。
学习小技巧：遇到疑似enthymeme时，可以问自己三件事：①说话者想让我相信什么结论？②他说出了哪些理由？③还有哪个关键前提被默认了？这个前提是否合理、是否有偏见？

summary.en: Entia is a philosophical term meaning “existing things” or “entities,” borrowed from Latin.
summary.zh: Entia 是借自拉丁语的哲学术语，意为“存在之物/实体”。

definition.en: Things that exist; entities (used mainly in philosophy, from Latin).
definition.zh: 存在之物；实体（主要用于哲学语境，源自拉丁语）。

examples.en: In medieval philosophy, scholars debated different kinds of entia, such as physical bodies and abstract forms.
examples.zh: 在中世纪哲学中，学者们讨论不同类型的 entia，例如物质身体与抽象形式。

examples.en: The theory tries to explain how many entia we should accept in our ontology.
examples.zh: 该理论试图解释在本体论中我们应当承认多少种 entia。

extraExplanation: “entia”是拉丁语“ens”（意为“存在者/存在之物”）的复数形式，在英语里多见于哲学、本体论与经院哲学讨论中，语气偏学术，不是日常用词。
在现代英语写作中，很多时候可直接用更常见的“entities”来替代；使用“entia”往往带有更强的哲学/拉丁学术传统色彩。

summary.en: “Entice” means to tempt or attract someone, usually by offering something appealing.
summary.zh: “Entice”表示用有吸引力的东西去诱惑或吸引某人（常指提供诱因）。

definition.en: To attract or persuade someone to do something by offering something appealing (often a reward or pleasure).
definition.zh: 用诱人的东西（常是奖励或享乐）来吸引或劝诱某人去做某事。

examples.en: The shop tried to entice customers with a big discount.
examples.zh: 这家店试图用大折扣来吸引顾客。

examples.en: He was enticed into joining the team by the promise of travel.
examples.zh: 他因为承诺可以旅行而被劝诱加入了团队。

examples.en: The smell of fresh bread enticed us to stop and buy some.
examples.zh: 新鲜面包的香味吸引我们停下来买了一些。

extraExplanation: “Entice”通常含有“让人难以抗拒的吸引力”，语气比“invite（邀请）”更强调“诱惑/引诱”。在某些语境下可能带一点负面含义（例如引诱做不该做的事），但也可以是中性的（如香味吸引人）。
词源上与“引诱、诱捕”的概念有关，因此常见搭配有：entice someone into doing something（引诱/劝诱某人做某事）、entice someone with something（用某物引诱某人）。

summary.en: “Enticeable” means “able to be enticed”—easy to attract or tempt into doing something.
summary.zh: “enticeable”表示“可被引诱的/容易被吸引去做某事的”。

definition.en: able to be persuaded, attracted, or tempted to do something (often by offering something pleasant or rewarding)
definition.zh: 可被引诱的；可被吸引或劝诱去做某事的（常因提供好处或诱因）

examples.en: Teenagers can be more enticeable when friends promise instant rewards.
examples.zh: 当朋友承诺立刻的好处时，青少年可能更容易被引诱。

examples.en: The discount made even cautious shoppers enticeable.
examples.zh: 折扣让连谨慎的顾客也变得容易被吸引。

extraExplanation: “enticeable”由动词 entice（引诱、诱使）+ 后缀 -able（可……的）构成，意思直观，但在现代英语中比较少见；更常见的表达是 “easily tempted / easily persuaded / susceptible to temptation”。
语气上，“entice”常暗示用吸引人的东西（如奖励、快乐、利益）来“勾起兴趣或欲望”；若要强调道德风险或负面诱惑，很多场合也会用 “tempt”。

summary.en: Enticed means “attracted/tempted,” and it is also the past form of “entice” (to persuade or lure).
summary.zh: Enticed 表示“被吸引/被诱惑”，也可作动词 entice 的过去式/过去分词，意为“引诱、劝诱”。

definition.en: attracted or tempted (often in a pleasant or persuasive way) to do something or to go somewhere
definition.zh: 被吸引或被诱使（常指以令人愉快或有说服力的方式）去做某事或去某处

examples.en: I was enticed by the smell of fresh bread and walked into the bakery.
examples.zh: 我被新鲜面包的香味吸引，走进了面包店。

examples.en: The ad enticed many people to try the new app.
examples.zh: 这则广告诱使很多人去试用这款新应用。

examples.en: She felt enticed to stay because everyone was so friendly.
examples.zh: 因为大家都很友好，她觉得很想留下来。

definition.en: past tense/past participle of “entice”: to attract or persuade someone to do something, sometimes in an improper or risky way
definition.zh: “entice”的过去式/过去分词：引诱、怂恿某人做某事；有时带有不正当或有风险的意味

examples.en: They enticed him into investing by promising quick profits.
examples.zh: 他们承诺快速获利，引诱他去投资。

examples.en: The free samples enticed customers to buy more.
examples.zh: 免费试吃吸引顾客买得更多。

extraExplanation: “entice”通常比“attract”更强调“让人动心去做某事”的感觉，常见搭配有：entice someone to do something / entice someone into doing something。
在某些语境（如法律、新闻）里，entice 可能带有“引诱他人做不当之事”的负面含义；日常生活中也可以是中性的，比如被美食、折扣“吸引”。

summary.en: Enticeful means “enticing/tempting,” but it’s rare and sounds old-fashioned; “enticing” is the common modern choice.
summary.zh: enticeful 意为“诱人的/吸引人的”，但非常罕见、偏古旧；现代英语更常用 enticing。

definition.en: (Rare/archaic) tempting; attractive in a way that makes someone want something.
definition.zh: （罕见/古旧）诱人的；有吸引力的，让人想要得到某物的。

examples.en: The smell of fresh bread was enticeful enough to pull us into the bakery.
examples.zh: 新鲜面包的香味很诱人，把我们吸引进了那家面包店。

examples.en: He described the job offer in such enticeful terms that I almost said yes immediately.
examples.zh: 他把那份工作机会说得非常诱人，我差点立刻就答应了。

extraExplanation: “enticeful”在现代英语中非常少见，多数情况下人们会用更常见自然的词：enticing / tempting / attractive。
词形上看像是“entice（引诱、吸引）+ -ful（充满……的）”，但在当代写作与口语里不算常用、可能会让读者觉得别扭或像拼写错误。若用于正式写作，建议改用“enticing”。

summary.en: An enticement is a lure or incentive, or the act of tempting someone to do something.
summary.zh: Enticement 指“诱因/诱惑”或“引诱他人做某事的行为”。

definition.en: Something that attracts or tempts someone to do something; an incentive or lure.
definition.zh: 引诱物；诱因；诱惑（使人去做某事的吸引力或诱因）。

examples.en: The company offered a signing bonus as an enticement to attract new employees.
examples.zh: 公司提供签约奖金作为吸引新员工的诱因。

examples.en: Free samples are a common enticement in supermarkets.
examples.zh: 免费试吃是超市里常见的促销诱因。

examples.en: He resisted the enticement of staying up late and went to bed early.
examples.zh: 他抵住了熬夜的诱惑，早早就睡了。

definition.en: The act of tempting or persuading someone to do something by offering pleasure, advantage, or a reward.
definition.zh: 引诱；诱使（通过利益、快乐或奖励来劝诱某人去做某事的行为）。

examples.en: Some people see gambling ads as enticement that can lead to unhealthy habits.
examples.zh: 有些人认为赌博广告是一种可能导致不良习惯的引诱。

examples.en: The law punishes the enticement of minors online.
examples.zh: 法律会惩罚在网上诱骗未成年人的行为。

extraExplanation: “Enticement”常带有“诱惑/引诱”的色彩，语气比中性的“incentive（激励/奖励）”更可能暗示不太光明或不够正当的动机，尤其在法律或道德语境中。
词源上与动词“entice（引诱）”相关，常见搭配有：an enticement to do sth（做某事的诱因）、the enticement of sth（某物的诱惑）。

summary.en: Enticements are offers or attractions that tempt or persuade someone.
summary.zh: Enticements 指用来诱使或说服他人的奖励、好处或吸引因素。

definition.en: things (offers, rewards, benefits, or attractions) that tempt or persuade someone to do something
definition.zh: 诱因；诱惑物（指用奖励、好处或吸引力来引诱或说服他人做某事的东西）

examples.en: The company offered higher pay and flexible hours as enticements to attract new staff.
examples.zh: 公司以更高薪资和弹性工时作为诱因来吸引新员工。

examples.en: Free samples are common enticements in supermarkets.
examples.zh: 免费试吃是超市里常见的诱惑手段。

examples.en: The promise of fame can be a powerful enticement for young performers.
examples.zh: 成名的承诺对年轻表演者来说可能是很强的诱因。

extraExplanation: “enticements”是“enticement”的复数形式。常见搭配：offer/provide enticements（提供诱因），use enticements to do sth（用诱因来做某事）。语气通常偏中性（营销、招聘等），但在谈到引诱他人做不道德或危险的事时也可能带负面含义。
词根提示：来自动词“entice”（引诱、诱使）。因此“enticement”更强调“用来引诱的东西/手段”，而不只是抽象的“吸引力”。

summary.en: Enticer means something or someone that tempts or attracts you into doing something.
summary.zh: Enticer 指“诱因/引诱者”，能吸引或诱使你去做某事的人或事物。

definition.en: A person or thing that attracts, tempts, or encourages someone to do something (often something pleasurable or slightly risky).
definition.zh: 引诱者；诱惑物：吸引、诱使或鼓动某人去做某事的人或事物（常与享乐或带点风险的事有关）。

examples.en: Free samples are a classic enticer that gets customers to try a new product.
examples.zh: 免费试吃是典型的“诱因”，能让顾客愿意尝试新产品。

examples.en: For many readers, the mysterious first chapter is an enticer to keep turning pages.
examples.zh: 对许多读者来说，神秘的第一章是一种“钩子”，让人忍不住继续往下读。

examples.en: The ad was designed as an enticer, promising quick results with little effort.
examples.zh: 这则广告被设计成一种诱惑手段，承诺不费力就能快速见效。

extraExplanation: “Enticer”来自动词“entice”（引诱、诱惑）+ 表示“……的人/物”的后缀“-er”，字面意思就是“用来引诱的东西/人”。日常英语里更常见的是动词“entice”或名词“temptation”（诱惑）；“enticer”相对少见，但在广告、营销或写作技巧（比如“hook”吸引读者的开头）语境中很实用。
语气提示：它通常带有“诱惑/引诱”的意味，可能是中性（如促销手段），也可能略带负面（如引人做不明智的事）。若想更中性，可用“incentive”（激励）或“attraction”（吸引力）。

summary.en: “Enticers” means people who tempt or persuade others, often in a misleading or risky way.
summary.zh: “Enticers”指引诱或怂恿他人的人，常带有欺骗或风险的含义。

definition.en: people who try to persuade, attract, or tempt others to do something (often something risky or wrong)
definition.zh: 引诱者；诱惑者；怂恿他人（常带负面含义）的人

examples.en: Online enticers sometimes pretend to be friendly to gain a teenager’s trust.
examples.zh: 网络上的引诱者有时会假装友好来获取青少年的信任。

examples.en: The scam warned customers about enticers offering “free” prizes.
examples.zh: 该骗局提醒顾客警惕那些用“免费”奖品来引诱人的人。

examples.en: Parents and schools work together to protect children from predators and other enticers.
examples.zh: 家长和学校共同努力，保护孩子远离捕食者和其他引诱者。

extraExplanation: “Enticers”是名词复数，单数是“enticer”（引诱者）。动词是“entice”，常见搭配：entice someone into doing something（引诱某人做某事）、entice someone with something（用某物诱惑某人）。
语气上，“entice/enticer”往往暗示不太正当或带风险的诱惑（例如骗局、非法活动）。如果只是中性地“吸引”，更常用“attract”。

summary.en: “Entices” means “attracts or tempts (someone),” often by offering something appealing.
summary.zh: “entices”表示“吸引或诱惑（某人）”，常通过提供有吸引力的事物来让对方行动。

definition.en: to attract or tempt someone by offering something pleasant or interesting, often so they will do something
definition.zh: 以愉快或有吸引力的事物引诱/吸引某人（常使其去做某事）

examples.en: The smell of fresh bread entices people into the bakery.
examples.zh: 新鲜面包的香味把人吸引进面包店。

examples.en: The app entices users with a free trial.
examples.zh: 这个应用用免费试用来吸引用户。

examples.en: He was enticed to join the club by the promise of new friends.
examples.zh: 他因为“能结交新朋友”的承诺而被吸引加入俱乐部。

definition.en: (sometimes) to lure someone in a way that is dishonest or risky
definition.zh: （有时）以不诚实或带风险的方式诱骗某人

examples.en: Scammers may entice people with fake prizes.
examples.zh: 骗子可能用虚假的奖品来诱骗他人。

examples.en: Be careful of links that entice you to share personal information.
examples.zh: 要小心那些诱使你分享个人信息的链接。

extraExplanation: “entices”是动词“entice”的第三人称单数形式（he/she/it entices）。常见搭配：entice sb into doing sth（引诱/吸引某人去做某事）、entice sb with sth（用某物吸引某人）。
语气通常比“attract”更强一点，带有“诱惑/劝诱”的感觉；在负面语境里接近“lure”（引诱、诱骗）。

summary.en: Enticing means very attractive or tempting—something that makes you want it.
summary.zh: enticing 指“很有吸引力、很诱人”，让人产生想要或想去做的感觉。

definition.en: Very attractive or tempting; making you want to do or have something.
definition.zh: 很吸引人的；很诱人的；让人想要去做或拥有某物的。

examples.en: The bakery’s enticing smell made me stop and buy a pastry.
examples.zh: 面包店诱人的香味让我停下来买了个点心。

examples.en: She offered an enticing discount to get new customers.
examples.zh: 她提供了很诱人的折扣来吸引新顾客。

extraExplanation: “Enticing”来自动词“entice”（引诱、吸引），常用来形容“让人很难拒绝”的事物：气味、食物、价格、机会、广告等。语气通常偏正面，但在涉及不诚实或危险的情境时也可能带一点“诱惑/引诱”的负面含义。
常见搭配：enticing offer（诱人的报价/条件）、enticing aroma（诱人的香气）、enticing opportunity（诱人的机会）、enticing smile（迷人的微笑）。相近词有“tempting”（更强调“想要/难以抗拒”）和“appealing”（更中性、强调“有吸引力”）。

summary.en: “Enticingly” means “in an attractive or tempting way.”
summary.zh: “enticingly”表示“以吸引人或诱人的方式”。

definition.en: In a way that attracts or tempts someone; in an appealing, inviting manner.
definition.zh: 以吸引人或诱人的方式；令人向往地、诱惑地。

examples.en: The bakery smelled enticingly sweet from the sidewalk.
examples.zh: 从人行道上就能闻到面包店里诱人的甜香味。

examples.en: The travel ad showed enticingly clear water and white sand.
examples.zh: 旅游广告展示了诱人的清澈海水和白色沙滩。

examples.en: She spoke enticingly about the new job opportunity.
examples.zh: 她用很吸引人的方式谈起那份新的工作机会。

extraExplanation: “enticingly”来自形容词“enticing”（诱人的、引人入胜的），动词根是“entice”（引诱、吸引）。在语气上，它通常偏中性到积极（像“很诱人、很有吸引力”），但在某些语境也可能带一点“引诱、勾引”的意味（取决于上下文）。
常见搭配：enticingly delicious（好吃得诱人）、enticingly close（近得很吸引人/让人心动）、enticingly simple（简单得让人想试试）、enticingly priced（价格很诱人）。

summary.en: Enticingness means the quality or degree of being enticing or attractive.
summary.zh: Enticingness 指“诱人/吸引人”的特质或程度。

definition.en: The quality of being enticing; attractiveness that makes someone want to do something, go somewhere, or have something.
definition.zh: “诱人”的特质；让人想去做某事、去某地或得到某物的吸引力。

examples.en: The enticingness of the dessert display made it hard to choose just one.
examples.zh: 甜点陈列的诱人程度让人很难只选一个。

examples.en: They relied on the enticingness of the job title to attract applicants, even though the pay was average.
examples.zh: 他们靠职位名称的诱人程度来吸引求职者，尽管薪水很普通。

extraExplanation: “Enticingness”是由形容词 enticing（诱人的）加名词后缀 -ness 构成，表示“……的性质/程度”。这个词在日常英语里不算常见，更自然的表达常用：appeal, attractiveness, allure, temptation（如：the appeal of…, the allure of…）。
语体提示：在学术写作或产品/营销分析中偶尔会用 enticingness 来强调“诱人程度”这一可衡量的特性；口语中通常会说 “how enticing it is” 或 “how appealing it is”。

summary.en: Entier means “whole/complete,” but it’s mainly archaic or used in heraldry; in everyday English, use “entire.”
summary.zh: Entier 表示“完整的/全部的”，但多为古语或纹章学用语；日常英语更常用 entire。

definition.en: (Archaic or literary) Whole; complete; entire.
definition.zh: （古语/文学用语）完整的；全部的；整体的。

examples.en: She offered an entier account of what happened that night.
examples.zh: 她对那晚发生的事做了完整的叙述。

examples.en: He devoted his entier attention to the task.
examples.zh: 他把全部注意力都投入到这项任务中。

definition.en: (Heraldry) Whole, not divided or cut; undivided.
definition.zh: （纹章学）未被分割的；完整不分的。

examples.en: In heraldry, an undivided shield may be described as entier.
examples.zh: 在纹章学中，未分割的盾形可称为 entier。

extraExplanation: “entier”源自古法语/中古法语，和现代英语“entire”（完整的）同源。现代英语里它很少单独使用，多见于旧文本、文学模仿或特定领域（如纹章学）。日常表达通常用“entire / whole / complete”。
注意拼写：你输入的“entier”不是常见的现代英语拼写；如果你想表达“整个的”，最常用的是“entire”。

summary.en: “Enties” is most commonly seen as part of decade/age expressions: “teens” (ages 13–19) and by extension “twenties/thirties…” for life stages.
summary.zh: “enties”多见于年龄/年代表达中：如“teens（13–19岁）”，并可类推到“twenties/thirties…”等人生阶段说法。

definition.en: (plural) Used after a number to name an age range or decade from 10 to 19 (or the years 1910–1919), most commonly in phrases like “in your teens.”
definition.zh: （复数）用于数字后，表示“10到19”的年龄段或年代（也可指1910–1919年），最常见于短语“in your teens（十几岁时）”。

examples.en: She started playing the guitar in her teens.
examples.zh: 她在十几岁时开始学吉他。

examples.en: Many people feel a lot of social pressure in their teens.
examples.zh: 很多人在十几岁时会感到很大的社交压力。

examples.en: The band became famous in the late teens of the 20th century.
examples.zh: 这支乐队在20世纪10年代末开始出名。

definition.en: (informal, plural) The twenties/thirties/etc.: the years of a person’s life from 20–29, 30–39, etc., especially when describing life stages.
definition.zh: （非正式，复数）如 the twenties/thirties 等：指一个人20–29岁、30–39岁等的阶段，常用来描述人生阶段。

examples.en: In my twenties, I moved to a new city and changed jobs twice.
examples.zh: 我二十多岁时搬到了新城市，还换了两次工作。

examples.en: He traveled a lot in his thirties.
examples.zh: 他三十多岁时旅行很多。

extraExplanation: “-teen”来自古英语，和“ten（十）”有关，所以 thirteen–nineteen（13–19）都带有 -teen。英语里更常说“in your teens / in your twenties”，而单独说“enties”并不常见；你更可能在“teens、twenties、thirties…”这类固定表达中看到它。

summary.en: Artificial means human-made (not natural), or not genuine/sincere.
summary.zh: Artificial 指“人造的/非天然的”，也可指“做作的/不真诚的”。

definition.en: Made or produced by humans rather than occurring naturally; not natural.
definition.zh: 人造的；人工制造的；非天然的

examples.en: The lake looks natural, but it’s actually artificial.
examples.zh: 这个湖看起来很自然，但其实是人工的。

examples.en: She wore artificial flowers in her hair.
examples.zh: 她在头发上戴了人造花。

definition.en: Not sincere or genuine; forced or unnatural in behavior or feeling.
definition.zh: 不真诚的；做作的；不自然的

examples.en: His smile felt artificial, like he was pretending to be happy.
examples.zh: 他的笑容显得很做作，像是在假装开心。

examples.en: The conversation became artificial after that awkward moment.
examples.zh: 那次尴尬之后，谈话变得不自然了。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“entifical”很可能是拼写错误，常见目标词是 **artificial**。记忆拼写的小技巧：arti-（像“art”艺术/人为）+ ficial（与“official”结尾类似）。
“artificial”既可以指“人造的”（artificial light 人工照明），也常用来形容“做作的/不真诚的”（an artificial laugh 假笑），语境不同含义会变化。

summary.en: Entification is a rare noun meaning the process of treating something as a separate, real entity.
summary.zh: Entification 是一个罕用名词，指把某事物当作独立真实的“实体”的过程（实体化）。

definition.en: (Rare) The act or process of making something into an “entity” (treating it as a separate, real thing).
definition.zh: （罕用）使某物成为“实体”的过程；把某事当作独立真实之物来对待（实体化）。

examples.en: Some critics argue that the entification of “the market” makes people forget it is shaped by human choices.
examples.zh: 一些评论者认为，把“市场”实体化会让人忘记它其实是由人的选择塑造的。

examples.en: The article warns against the entification of culture as if it were one fixed thing.
examples.zh: 这篇文章提醒人们不要把文化实体化，好像它是一个固定不变的东西。

extraExplanation: “entification”在日常英语里非常少见，很多时候是把“identification（识别/身份确认）”或“authentication（认证）”拼错了。
在学术语境（尤其是哲学/社会科学写作）中，它接近“reification（物化/实体化）”的意思：把抽象概念当成具体、独立存在的东西。

summary.en: “entify” is not standard English; you probably mean “identify,” meaning to recognize or determine exactly what someone/something is.
summary.zh: “entify”不是标准英语；你大概率想写“identify”，表示“辨认/认出”或“查明、确认”。

definition.en: (Common misspelling) Usually intended to mean “identify”: to recognize or name someone or something, or to find out exactly what it is.
definition.zh: （常见拼写错误）通常想表达 identify：辨认/认出某人或某物；或查明、确定其身份或性质。

examples.en: Could you identify the person in this photo?
examples.zh: 你能辨认出这张照片里的人吗？

examples.en: The police are trying to identify the cause of the fire.
examples.zh: 警方正在努力查明火灾原因。

extraExplanation: “entify”不是标准英语单词，最常见情况是把“identify”拼错了（少了字母 i 和 d）。
拼写小提示：i + dent（“dent”像“痕迹/凹痕”，帮助记住中间的 -dent-）+ i + fy。

summary.en: Entincture means to tint or give a slight coloring or quality (a rare, literary verb).
summary.zh: Entincture 指“使……带上一点颜色或特质”，是较少见、偏文学的动词。

definition.en: (Rare/archaic) To tint or stain something; to give something a slight color or quality.
definition.zh: （罕见/古体）给……染色、着色；使……带上一点颜色或性质（气息）。

examples.en: The sunset seemed to entincture the clouds with pink.
examples.zh: 夕阳仿佛把云朵染上了粉红色。

examples.en: Years of travel entinctured his writing with a quiet sense of wonder.
examples.zh: 多年的旅行让他的文字带上了一种安静的惊奇感。

extraExplanation: “entincture”在现代英语中非常少见，多见于较旧的文学或修辞性写作；日常更常用的是“tint / stain / tinge / imbue”。
词形上可理解为 en-（使……进入某种状态）+ tincture（染色、酊剂；源自拉丁语 tingere“染色”）。在比喻用法里，它常表示“给思想/性格/文字添上一点某种色彩”。

summary.en: Entire means “whole or complete,” often used to emphasize that nothing is missing.
summary.zh: Entire 表示“全部的、完整的”，常用来强调“没有任何缺失”。

definition.en: Whole; complete; with nothing missing.
definition.zh: 全部的；完整的；一点也不缺的。

examples.en: I read the entire book in one weekend.
examples.zh: 我一个周末就把整本书读完了。

examples.en: The entire team agreed with the plan.
examples.zh: 整个团队都同意这个计划。

examples.en: We spent the entire day at the museum.
examples.zh: 我们一整天都待在博物馆里。

definition.en: (Used for emphasis) Complete and total in degree.
definition.zh: （用于强调）完全的；彻底的（程度上完全）。

examples.en: That idea is an entire misunderstanding of the problem.
examples.zh: 那个想法完全误解了这个问题。

examples.en: Her explanation was an entire surprise to me.
examples.zh: 她的解释让我非常意外（简直出乎意料）。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配是“the entire + 名词”（the entire world/whole day），更强调“作为一个整体”。“an entire + 单数可数名词”常表示“一整个/足足一个”（an entire week）。
注意词形：副词是 entirely（完全地）。不要把 entire 当作副词用（应说 entirely wrong，而不是 *entire wrong）。
entire 与 whole 很接近：口语中 whole 更常见（the whole thing），entire 稍更正式（the entire process）。

summary.en: “Entirely” means “completely/fully,” and it’s often used in the phrase “not entirely” to mean “not completely.”
summary.zh: “Entirely”表示“完全地/彻底地”，并常用于“not entirely”表示“并不完全”。

definition.en: completely; totally; in every way or to the full extent
definition.zh: 完全地；彻底地；全部地

examples.en: I entirely agree with you.
examples.zh: 我完全同意你。

examples.en: The plan was entirely new to us.
examples.zh: 这个计划对我们来说完全是新的。

examples.en: She was entirely focused on her work.
examples.zh: 她完全专注于工作。

definition.en: only; solely (often used with a negative: “not entirely”)
definition.zh: （强调范围）仅仅；完全算不上（常用于否定：not entirely）

examples.en: I’m not entirely sure what he meant.
examples.zh: 我不太确定他是什么意思。

examples.en: The problem isn’t entirely your fault.
examples.zh: 这个问题不完全是你的错。

extraExplanation: “Entirely”来自“entire（完整的）+ -ly（副词后缀）”，语气比“completely”更偏“整体/全部”。日常口语里，“not entirely”很常见，语气更委婉，常用于表达“并非完全如此/不太”。

summary.en: Entireness means the state of being whole and complete.
summary.zh: Entireness 指“整体、完整无缺的状态”。

definition.en: The state of being whole and complete; total wholeness.
definition.zh: 完整的状态；整体性；完备性。

examples.en: The judge considered the evidence in its entireness, not just one detail.
examples.zh: 法官从整体上考虑证据，而不只看某一个细节。

examples.en: To understand the story, read the chapter in its entireness.
examples.zh: 要理解这个故事，请把这一章完整地读完。

extraExplanation: “entireness”是由 entire（完整的）+ -ness（名词后缀）构成，但在现代英语中不算常用；更常见、更自然的表达通常是 “wholeness”“completeness” 或 “the whole/entirety”。
在学术写作或较正式的语境里，你也可能看到 “in its entirety”（整体上；完整地）这种固定搭配，比 “in its entireness” 更常见。

summary.en: “Entires” is uncommon; it’s usually related to “entire” (whole/complete). Many learners actually mean “entries” (records/items).
summary.zh: “entires”并不常用，通常与“entire（全部的/完整的）”有关；很多学习者其实想写的是“entries（条目/记录）”。

definition.en: (plural form of “entire”) whole; complete; not divided or missing any parts.
definition.zh: （“entire”的复数形式）全部的；完整的；没有缺失或被分开的。

examples.en: They ate two entire pizzas by themselves.
examples.zh: 他们自己吃掉了两整张披萨。

examples.en: The entire class agreed with the plan.
examples.zh: 全班都同意这个计划。

definition.en: (rare, plural noun) whole things considered as complete units; entireties.
definition.zh: （罕见，复数名词）整体；完整的事物（相当于 entireties）。

examples.en: The law protects the entires of certain estates. (rare/formal)
examples.zh: 法律保护某些地产的整体（罕见/正式用法）。

extraExplanation: “entires”在现代英语里最常见只是形容词“entire”的复数（修饰复数名词时，形式仍写 entire，不写 entires：the entire books ✗；应为 the entire book 或 the whole books / all the books）。因此你输入的“entires”很可能是拼写误用。
如果你想表达“条目/记录”，正确拼写通常是 “entries”（entry 的复数），比如 journal entries（日记/账目条目）。
常用相关表达：in its entirety（整体上；全部地），例如：I read the report in its entirety（我把报告从头到尾读完了）。

summary.en: “Entireties” is the plural of “entirety,” meaning “wholes/complete forms,” and it can also refer to multiple cases of the legal term “tenancy by the entireties.”
summary.zh: “Entireties”是“entirety”的复数，表示“整体/完整版本”；在法律语境中也可指多处“夫妻共同共有（tenancy by the entireties）”的安排。

definition.en: the whole of something; everything considered together (plural of “entirety”)
definition.zh: 整体；全部（“entirety”的复数）

examples.en: You can’t judge the project from one mistake—you need to look at it in its entireties.
examples.zh: 你不能因为一个错误就评判这个项目——要从整体来看。

examples.en: The documentary shows the two events in their entireties, not as short clips.
examples.zh: 这部纪录片把两件事完整呈现，而不是只放一些片段。

definition.en: (law) a form of joint ownership by a married couple, usually referring to “tenancy by the entireties” (plural uses refer to multiple such arrangements)
definition.zh: （法律）夫妻共同共有的一种形式，通常指“tenancy by the entireties（夫妻共同共有）”；复数可指多段此类所有权安排

examples.en: In some states, the house was held in tenancy by the entireties.
examples.zh: 在一些州，这套房子以夫妻共同共有的方式持有。

examples.en: Their lawyer reviewed the entireties in the property records.
examples.zh: 他们的律师审查了房产记录中的夫妻共同共有条款/安排。

extraExplanation: “entireties”在日常英语里不如“in its entirety（完整地/作为整体）”常见；很多时候更自然的说法是“the whole thing”或“the complete version”。
法律用法“tenancy by the entireties”主要见于美国财产法语境：通常只适用于已婚夫妻，并且在某些情况下可对一方个人债务提供一定保护（具体取决于州法）。

summary.en: Entirety means the whole of something—everything as a complete unit.
summary.zh: Entirety 指“整体、全部”，强调把某事物作为一个完整单位或全部范围来看。

definition.en: the whole of something; everything considered as a complete unit
definition.zh: 整体；全部；全体（把某事物作为一个完整单位来看）

examples.en: I read the book in its entirety.
examples.zh: 我把这本书从头到尾完整读了一遍。

examples.en: The report, taken in its entirety, is fairly positive.
examples.zh: 如果把这份报告整体来看，它相当正面。

definition.en: the complete amount or extent of something (often used with “the entirety of…”)
definition.zh: 全部数量；全部范围（常与“the entirety of…”连用）

examples.en: The storm affected the entirety of the coastline.
examples.zh: 这场风暴影响了整段海岸线。

examples.en: They donated the entirety of the prize money to charity.
examples.zh: 他们把全部奖金都捐给了慈善机构。

extraExplanation: “in its entirety”是非常常见的固定搭配，语气偏正式，常用于写作、新闻和学术语境，强调“完整地、整体地看”。
“the entirety of + 名词”也偏正式，相当于“all of / the whole of”，但更强调“没有遗漏的全部”。
注意：entirety是名词；形容词形式是entire（例如：the entire book 整本书）。

summary.en: “Enteritis” means inflammation of the intestines (a medical term).
summary.zh: “Enteritis”指肠炎（肠道发炎的医学用语）。

definition.en: (Medical) Inflammation of the intestines, especially the small intestine, often causing diarrhea and stomach pain.
definition.zh: （医学）肠炎；肠道（尤指小肠）发炎，常引起腹泻与腹痛。

examples.en: The doctor said the child likely has enteritis caused by a virus.
examples.zh: 医生说这个孩子可能是病毒引起的肠炎。

examples.en: Symptoms of enteritis can include diarrhea, cramps, and nausea.
examples.zh: 肠炎的症状可能包括腹泻、痉挛和恶心。

examples.en: To prevent enteritis, wash your hands well and avoid unsafe food or water.
examples.zh: 为了预防肠炎，要勤洗手，并避免不安全的食物或饮用水。

extraExplanation: “entiris”不是常见英文单词。你可能想写的是 **enteritis**（肠炎），这是医学用语。
词源：enter- 表示“肠”（来自希腊语），-itis 表示“炎症”（常见于 tonsillitis 扁桃体炎、bronchitis 支气管炎 等）。
日常英语里更常用的说法可能是 **stomach bug**（肠胃病毒/肠胃炎的口语说法）、**intestinal infection**（肠道感染）或 **gastroenteritis**（胃肠炎）。如果你想查的是别的词（比如 entire/entirety），告诉我你看到它的句子，我可以帮你确认。

summary.en: “Entities” is the plural of “entity,” meaning distinct things or organizations that exist as separate units.
summary.zh: “Entities” 是 “entity” 的复数，指独立存在、可区分的个体或机构/实体。

definition.en: plural of entity: a thing that exists as a separate, distinct unit (a person, organization, object, or concept).
definition.zh: entity 的复数：独立存在、可被区分的“个体/实体”（可以是人、组织、物体或概念）。

examples.en: The database stores customer entities such as people and companies.
examples.zh: 这个数据库保存客户实体，比如个人和公司。

examples.en: In the story, the forest spirit is a mysterious entity.
examples.zh: 在故事里，森林精灵是一个神秘的存在。

definition.en: (Business/Law) Organizations or bodies recognized as distinct units, often with legal or administrative identity.
definition.zh: （商业/法律）被视为独立单位的机构/团体，通常具有法律或管理上的身份。

examples.en: Several entities signed the agreement, including two charities.
examples.zh: 多个机构签署了协议，包括两家慈善组织。

examples.en: The company operates through different legal entities in different countries.
examples.zh: 这家公司在不同国家通过不同的法人实体运营。

extraExplanation: “entirities” 常见为拼写错误，正确拼写是 “entities”。单数是 “entity”。
在科技/数据领域（如数据库、API、知识图谱）里，entity 常指“可被识别和描述的对象”（例如用户、订单、公司）。

summary.en: “Entitative” means relating to an entity or treating something as a distinct independent thing, mainly used in academic contexts.
summary.zh: “entitative”指与“实体”有关或把某事物当作独立存在的“实体”来看待，多用于学术语境。

definition.en: Relating to an entity; considered as a distinct, independent thing (especially in philosophy or logic).
definition.zh: （尤指哲学或逻辑中）与“实体/个体”有关的；被当作一个独立存在的事物来看待的。

examples.en: In the debate, the mind was treated as an entitative thing rather than a process.
examples.zh: 在那场讨论中，心灵被当作一个独立的实体，而不是一个过程。

examples.en: Some theories reject entitative explanations and focus on relationships instead.
examples.zh: 一些理论拒绝“实体化”的解释，而是关注关系本身。

extraExplanation: 该词较少用于日常英语，更常见于学术写作（哲学、形而上学、逻辑、神学、社会理论等）。
词源上与 entity（实体）有关；很多时候可以用更常见的说法替换，如 entity-based（以实体为基础的）、as an entity（作为一个实体）、treat X as a thing（把X当作一个“东西/对象”）。
常见搭配：entitative view/approach（实体化的观点/方法）、entitative explanation（实体化解释）、entitative being（作为实体的存在）。注意它通常在讨论“把某种现象当作独立对象”这种思想时出现。

summary.en: Entitatively means “as a distinct entity,” especially in formal or academic contexts.
summary.zh: entitatively 意为“作为一个独立实体地”，多用于正式或学术语境。

definition.en: In a way that treats something as a distinct entity; with regard to its separate existence or identity.
definition.zh: 以“实体/独立存在者”的方式；从其作为独立个体的存在或身份来讲。

examples.en: Legally, the company is treated entitatively, separate from its owners.
examples.zh: 在法律上，公司被以实体的方式对待，与其所有者相区分。

examples.en: In philosophy, we can discuss a concept entitatively, as if it were a thing.
examples.zh: 在哲学中，我们可以从实体的角度讨论一个概念，仿佛它是一种“事物”。

examples.en: The data were analyzed entitatively, focusing on each unit rather than the whole system.
examples.zh: 这些数据以实体化的方式进行分析，关注每个单元而不是整体系统。

extraExplanation: “entitatively”常见于哲学、神学、法学等偏学术的语境，强调把某物当作“一个独立的存在者（entity）”来理解或讨论。
它与更常见的表达“as an entity / as a separate entity（作为一个独立实体）”意思接近；在日常英语中，通常用后者更自然。

summary.en: “Entities” means separate things or organizations, especially in formal contexts like law, business, or computing; it is the plural of “entity.”
summary.zh: “Entities”是“entity”的复数，指独立存在的事物或机构，尤常用于法律、商业或计算机等正式语境。

definition.en: Things that exist as individual units, especially in a particular context (such as law, business, or computing).
definition.zh: 实体；独立存在的事物（尤指在法律、商业或计算机等语境中）。

examples.en: In this report, the entities include the company, its customers, and its suppliers.
examples.zh: 在这份报告中，实体包括公司、其客户以及供应商。

examples.en: Each country is treated as a separate entity in the agreement.
examples.zh: 在这项协议中，每个国家都被视为一个独立实体。

definition.en: Organizations or bodies with a distinct identity and purpose (for example, a company, agency, or institution).
definition.zh: 机构；组织（具有独立身份与目的，例如公司、政府部门或机构）。

examples.en: Several entities joined together to fund the project.
examples.zh: 多个机构联合出资支持该项目。

examples.en: The law applies to private entities as well as public ones.
examples.zh: 这项法律既适用于私营机构，也适用于公共机构。

definition.en: In data and software, a real-world object or concept that can be represented in a database (often with attributes), such as “User,” “Order,” or “Product.”
definition.zh: （数据/软件）实体：可在数据库中表示的现实对象或概念（通常带有属性），如“用户”“订单”“产品”。

examples.en: In the database, “Customer” is an entity with attributes like name and email.
examples.zh: 在数据库中，“客户”是一个实体，具有姓名、邮箱等属性。

examples.en: We need to define the entities and their relationships before building the app.
examples.zh: 在开发应用前，我们需要先定义实体及其关系。

extraExplanation: “entities”是“entity”的复数形式。日常英语里可以泛指“事物/个体”，但在正式语境（法律、商业、学术、计算机）中特别常见，强调“可被单独识别、可被界定边界”的单位。
常见搭配：legal entities（法律实体）、business entities（商业实体）、government entities（政府机构）、separate/distinct entity（独立实体）。
在数据库语境中，entity 常与 attribute（属性）、relationship（关系）一起出现：entity-relationship model（实体—关系模型，ER 模型）。

summary.en: Entitle mainly means to give someone an official right to something, and it can also mean to name a book or work.
summary.zh: entitle 主要表示“使某人有权获得某物/做某事”，也可表示“给作品命名/加标题”。

definition.en: to give someone the official right to have or do something
definition.zh: 使某人有权（依法或按规定）获得某物或做某事

examples.en: This ticket entitles you to a free drink.
examples.zh: 这张票使你有权领取一杯免费饮料。

examples.en: Employees are entitled to paid vacation after one year.
examples.zh: 员工工作满一年后有权享受带薪休假。

definition.en: to give a title or name to a book, film, or work of art
definition.zh: 给（书、电影或艺术作品）命名；加标题

examples.en: She entitled her essay “Small Acts of Kindness.”
examples.zh: 她把自己的文章命名为《微小的善举》。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：be entitled to + 名词/动名词，表示“有权……/应得……”。例如：be entitled to compensation（有权获得赔偿）。
注意语气区别：entitled（形容词）还可表示“自以为有资格、理所当然”的负面态度（如 an entitled attitude），这与动词 entitle（赋予权利）不同。

summary.en: “Entitled” most commonly means having an official right to something; it can also describe a person who expects special treatment, or something that has a title.
summary.zh: “Entitled”最常见意思是“有权获得/有资格”；也可形容人“自以为理应被特殊对待”（多贬义），或表示“题为/名为”。

definition.en: (often + to) having the legal or official right to have or do something.
definition.zh: （常与 to 连用）有合法或正式权利去获得某物或做某事的。

examples.en: You are entitled to a full refund if the product is faulty.
examples.zh: 如果产品有瑕疵，你有权获得全额退款。

examples.en: All employees are entitled to paid vacation.
examples.zh: 所有员工都有权享受带薪休假。

definition.en: believing you deserve special treatment or more than others (often seen as negative).
definition.zh: （常带贬义）自认为理应得到特殊对待或比别人更多的（有优越感/“理所当然”心态的）。

examples.en: He acts entitled and gets angry when things don’t go his way.
examples.zh: 他表现得很“理所当然”，事情不如意就生气。

examples.en: Some customers feel entitled to immediate service.
examples.zh: 有些顾客觉得自己理应立刻得到服务。

definition.en: given a title; named or called something.
definition.zh: 有标题的；被命名为……的。

examples.en: The book is entitled “The Great Gatsby.”
examples.zh: 这本书的书名是《了不起的盖茨比》。

extraExplanation: 用法提示：①“be entitled to + 名词/动名词”强调“依法/按规定有权……”，常用于合同、政策、福利等正式语境。②形容人“entitled”多指一种让人反感的态度（觉得别人欠他的），语气偏负面；如果想表达中性“有自信/有主见”，不要用 entitled。
与“titled”区别：在现代英语里，表示“书/电影名为……”时，口语和写作中常用 “titled”。“entitled”也可以这样用，但在某些风格指南里更推荐“titled”来避免与“有权”混淆。

summary.en: Entitledness is a sense that you deserve special treatment or something you want, often without earning it.
summary.zh: Entitledness 指一种觉得自己理应得到特殊待遇或想要的东西的心态，往往带有不一定靠努力获得的意味。

definition.en: A belief that you deserve special treatment, privileges, or rewards, often without earning them.
definition.zh: 一种认为自己理应得到特殊待遇、特权或回报的心态，常带有“不需要付出也该得到”的感觉。

examples.en: Her entitledness made her angry when she had to wait in line like everyone else.
examples.zh: 她的“理所当然心态”让她在不得不像所有人一样排队时很生气。

examples.en: A sense of entitledness can hurt teamwork because it ignores other people’s efforts.
examples.zh: 一种强烈的优越/理所当然心态会伤害团队合作，因为它忽视了他人的付出。

definition.en: A confident feeling that you have a right to something; in some contexts, this can be neutral or positive (though the word often sounds negative).
definition.zh: 一种认为自己“有权得到某物”的信念；在某些语境下可中性或偏正面（但这个词通常带负面色彩）。

examples.en: After years of unpaid overtime, he felt a justified entitledness to fair compensation.
examples.zh: 在多年无偿加班后，他觉得自己理应得到公平的补偿。

examples.en: People sometimes confuse self-respect with entitledness.
examples.zh: 人们有时会把自尊和“理所当然心态”混为一谈。

extraExplanation: “entitledness”通常由形容词“entitled（自以为应得的）”加名词后缀“-ness”构成，强调一种持续的性格/心态特征。
